title: Deacon: Hierarchical health-check orchestrator
description:
Replace daemon heartbeats with Deacon - an AI agent that keeps Gas Town running.

## Core Concept

The Deacon is a **Claude agent** (not just a Go process) that:
- Lives at town root in gt-deacon session
- Has its own mailbox (deacon/ identity in town beads)
- Is poked by a minimal Go daemon every ~60s (if idle)
- Monitors Mayor and Witnesses proactively
- Handles lifecycle requests (restart/cycle) from Mayor, Witnesses, AND Crew

## Architecture

```
Minimal Go Daemon (just watches Deacon)
         |
         v
     Deacon (Claude agent)
         |
    +----+----+
    v         v
  Mayor    Witnesses --> Polecats (Witness-managed)
    |         |
    +----+----+
         |
      Crew (lifecycle only, not monitored)
```

## Deacon Responsibilities

**Proactive monitoring:**
- Mayor health (tmux session, keepalive freshness)
- Witness health (tmux sessions, keepalive freshness)

**Reactive lifecycle:**
- Process restart/cycle requests from Mayor, Witnesses, Crew
- Kill session, create new, prime, verify startup

**Escalation:**
- Mail human (configurable) if issues can't be resolved

## Key Files

- ~/gt/DEACON.md - Role context
- ~/gt/deacon/ - State directory
  - heartbeat.json - Written each wake cycle (daemon checks this)
  - state.json - Health tracking, last scan results
- ~/gt/.beads/ - Town beads with deacon/ mail identity

## Wake Cycle

1. Write heartbeat (prevents daemon from poking)
2. Check mail (lifecycle requests)
3. Quick health scan (Mayor, Witnesses)
4. Process lifecycle requests
5. Remediate unhealthy agents
6. Update state

## Session Patterns

- Deacon: gt-deacon
- Mayor: gt-mayor
- Witness: gt-<rig>-witness
- Crew: gt-<rig>-<name> (e.g., gt-gastown-max)

## Relation to Policy Beads

Future: Deacon behavior configurable via policy beads (gt-3zw).
Initial implementation uses sensible defaults.

title: ZFC #9: Explicit MR registration instead of branch parsing
description:
**ZFC Violation:** internal/refinery/manager.go:346-370

Go infers work metadata from branch naming conventions:
```go
pattern := regexp.MustCompile(`^polecat/([^/]+)(?:/(.+))?$`)
worker := matches[1]
issueID = matches[2]
```

**ZFC-compliant solution:**
Polecats register MRs with explicit structured data:
- `gt mq submit --worker=nux --issue=gt-xyz --branch=polecat/nux/gt-xyz`
- Creates MR bead with explicit fields
- No regex parsing of branch names

**Benefits:**
- Work metadata is explicit, not inferred
- Branch naming can evolve without breaking refinery
- Audit trail in beads

Reference: ~/gt/docs/zfc-violations-audit.md #9

title: Molecule await-signal step type
description:
Add await-signal as a molecule step type for patrol agents.

## Step Definition

```toml
[[steps]]
id = "await-signal"
type = "wait"
backoff = { base = "30s", multiplier = 2, max = "10m" }
description = "Wait for signal, then check reality"
```

## Behavior

1. Sleep for current backoff interval
2. Wake immediately on nudge (or timeout expires)
3. Proceed to next step (check-reality)
4. If no work found, loop back with increased backoff
5. If work found, reset backoff to base

## Implementation Options

A. Formula-level: Define in TOML, agent interprets
B. Code-level: Agent implements wait loop with backoff

Option A is cleaner but needs formula parser support.
Option B works now but less declarative.

## Used By

- mol-witness-patrol (first step)
- mol-refinery-patrol (first step)

title: Runtime dynamic expansion (for-each)
description:
Implement runtime expansion for discovered work (the for-each construct).

## Syntax

    step: survey-workers
    on-complete:
      for-each: output.polecats
      bond: mol-polecat-arm
      vars:
        polecat_name: "{item.name}"
        rig: "{item.rig}"
      parallel: true  # or sequential: true

## Design Context (from gt-8tmz.4 review)

This is **control flow**, not just expansion. It affects execution order:
- for-each with parallel: true = concurrent child execution
- for-each with sequential: true = ordered child execution

Key patrol patterns that require this:

| Pattern | Use Case |
|---------|----------|
| Witness survey-workers | For each polecat, bond an arm (parallel) |
| Refinery process-branch | For each branch in queue, run merge pipeline (sequential) |
| Deacon plugin-run | For each plugin where gate open, execute |

## Relationship to gt-8tmz.4

gt-8tmz.4 implements loop, gate, branch (static control flow).
This issue implements for-each (dynamic control flow over runtime-discovered collections).

Together they cover the full control flow needs for patrol formulas.

## Implementation Notes

- Bonds N instances based on step output
- Christmas Ornament pattern: fanout from single step to N parallel children
- Pairs with waits-for gate (gt-8tmz.38) for aggregation
- Collection must be iterable (array in step output)
- Each iteration gets item, index, and parent context in vars

title: Fix namepool Save() to use write lock
description:
attached_args: Fix namepool Save() mutex for thread safety

Fix incorrect mutex usage in namepool Save() method.

## Files to modify
- internal/polecat/namepool.go

## Problem (lines 179-194)
Save() uses RLock() but performs file I/O:
```go
func (p *NamePool) Save() error {
    p.mu.RLock()  // WRONG: file write needs write lock
    defer p.mu.RUnlock()
    // ... file operations ...
}
```

## Fix
Change to write lock:
```go
func (p *NamePool) Save() error {
    p.mu.Lock()
    defer p.mu.Unlock()
    // ... file operations ...
}
```

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] Save() uses Lock() instead of RLock()
- [ ] go test -race ./internal/polecat/... passes
- [ ] Existing namepool tests still pass

title: Step recovery: timeout and release
description:
Implement recovery mechanism for stuck molecule steps.

## Problem
When a worker dies mid-step, the step stays in_progress forever.
Need timeout/release mechanism for nondeterministic idempotence.

## Solution
1. Track step start time (claimed_at timestamp)
2. Timeout: After 30 min in_progress, step returns to pending
3. Manual release: bd release <step-id>

## Implementation Options

### Option A: Beads-level timeout
- Add claimed_at field to issues
- bd ready excludes items in_progress < 30 min
- bd ready includes items in_progress > 30 min (auto-recovery)

### Option B: Daemon-level timeout  
- Daemon watches in_progress items
- Moves back to pending after timeout

### Option C: Manual only (MVP)
- bd release <id> manually moves in_progress → pending
- Document recovery procedure
- Witness can automate for polecats

## Recommendation
Start with Option C (manual) for Christmas. Add Option A later.

## Acceptance
- [ ] bd release command works
- [ ] Stuck steps can be recovered
- [ ] Documented recovery procedure

title: Epic: Wisp Molecule Integration
description:
## Vision

Integrate Beads wisp molecules into Gas Town. All orchestration work runs as wisp molecules - patrols, polecat workflows, batch operations. Only digests reach main beads.

## The Steam Engine Metaphor

```
Engine does work → generates steam
Steam wisps rise → execution trace
Steam condenses → digest (distillate)  
Steam dissipates → cleaned up (burned)
```

## Architecture

```
Proto Molecules (templates)
    ↓ bd mol bond
Wisps (.beads-wisps/ or inline)
    ↓ bd mol squash + AI summary
Main Beads (digests only)
```

## Vocabulary

| Term | Meaning |
|------|---------|
| bond | Attach proto to work (creates wisps) |
| wisp | Temporary execution step (steam rising) |
| squash | Condense wisps into digest |
| burn | Destroy wisps without record |
| digest | Permanent condensed record (distillate) |

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Wisp location**: Per-rig or inline in main beads with wisp flag
2. **Summary generation**: Agent that did work generates summary (inversion of control)
3. **Squash timing**: Final step of molecule workflow, before signaling done
4. **Crash recovery**: Wisps persist, Witness detects stalls, new agent resumes
5. **Patrols**: Each cycle is fresh wisp molecule, squashed on completion

## Digest Contents

- Molecule type and instance ID
- Assignee, start/end times
- Source issue reference
- AI-generated summary
- Outcomes (issues closed, commits, branches)

## Integration Points

- gt rig init: Configure wisp storage
- gt spawn --molecule: Bond creates wisps
- gt prime: Show wisp molecule context
- Polecat CLAUDE.md: Summary + squash protocol
- gt doctor: Wisp health checks
- Deacon/Witness/Refinery: Patrol molecules

## Phases

Phase 1: Wisp setup infrastructure
Phase 2: Spawn integration
Phase 3: Completion flow (summary + squash)
Phase 4: Patrol integration
Phase 5: Documentation and polish

title: Mol Mall: Molecule marketplace distribution
description:
Design the Mol Mall distribution mechanism for sharing molecules.

## Core Insight

Mol Mall is just a registry of molecules.jsonl fragments. No special format needed.

## Distribution Model

```
Mol Mall (registry)
    │
    │ bd mol search "security"
    ▼
Molecule catalog (searchable index)
    │
    │ bd mol install mol-security-scan
    ▼
Download molecules.jsonl fragment
    │
    │ Append to ~/.beads/molecules.jsonl
    ▼
Available locally: bd mol list
```

## Registry Format

Simple JSON index served from HTTPS:

```json
{
  "molecules": [
    {
      "id": "mol-security-scan",
      "title": "Security Scan",
      "description": "OWASP Top 10 vulnerability checker",
      "labels": ["plugin", "code-review", "tier:sonnet"],
      "author": "anthropic",
      "version": "1.0.0",
      "url": "https://mol-mall.anthropic.com/molecules/mol-security-scan.jsonl"
    }
  ]
}
```

## CLI Commands

```bash
bd mol search <query>           # Search registry
bd mol info <id>                # Show molecule details
bd mol install <id>             # Download and install
bd mol uninstall <id>           # Remove from catalog
bd mol update                   # Update all installed molecules
```

## Installation Locations

```
~/.beads/molecules.jsonl        # User-level (default install location)
~/gt/.beads/molecules.jsonl     # Town-level (shared across rigs)
.beads/molecules.jsonl          # Project-level (team-specific)
```

## Version Management

Molecules can have versions via labels: `version:1.0.0`
Install specific version: `bd mol install mol-security-scan@1.0.0`

## Auth (Future)

Private registries could require auth token.
Enterprise Mol Malls for internal distribution.

## Related

- gt-u818: Plugin System (plugins ARE molecules)
- molecular-chemistry.md: Format documentation

title: Epic: Merge Queue Scaling
description:
Scale the merge queue beyond 20 polecats per rig.

## Current Limits
- Serial MQ works well for 5-20 polecats
- Conflict rate increases with polecat count and task duration
- At 50+ polecats, conflicts become frequent enough to bottleneck

## Scaling Strategies (in order of implementation)

### Phase 1: Smart Scheduling
- Track file hotspots (which files change most)
- Conflict prediction before spawn (warn if touching hot files)
- Dependency-aware reordering (maximize parallel non-conflicting merges)
- Priority lanes (P0 jumps queue)

### Phase 2: Ownership Zones
- Partition code by ownership (team-a owns auth/, team-b owns payments/)
- Serialize access to shared/hot zones
- Parallelize work in non-overlapping zones

### Phase 3: Speculative Execution
- Refinery pool (multiple refineries try merges in parallel)
- First to pass CI wins, losers rebase and retry
- Requires cheap CI and tolerance for wasted compute

### Phase 4: Semantic Resolution
- AI understands change intent, not just diffs
- Re-implement changes on new baseline when rebase fails
- Detect incompatible intents → escalate to human

## Key Insight
The merge queue is fundamentally a serialization bottleneck. Solutions either:
1. Reduce staleness (faster work, continuous rebasing)
2. Reduce conflicts (partition code, ownership zones)
3. Resolve conflicts (smart merge, semantic understanding)
4. Avoid conflicts (predictive scheduling)

## Related
- gt-gmqe: Bare repo architecture (foundation for this)
- gt-4u5z: Worktree design (precursor)

title: Outpost assignment policy: Smart work routing
Hook ergonomics: auto-replace completed pins
description:
## Problem

When pinning a new bead, if the old pinned bead is complete, the new pin should automatically replace it. Currently this fails and requires manual unpinning (which doesn't exist as a command).

Observed friction:
1. Old patrol wisp 100% complete, still pinned
2. Created new patrol wisp
3. `gt mol attach` failed: 'not pinned'
4. Tried to close old wisp: 'cannot close pinned issue'
5. Tried `gt hook unpin`: command doesn't exist
6. Stuck in limbo

## Proposed fix

- `gt hook <new-bead>` auto-replaces if old pin is complete
- Require `--force` if old pin is incomplete
- `gt mol attach` should auto-pin if bead isn't pinned

## Orphan detection

Unpinned incomplete molecules aren't stale orphans until they create graph pressure (blocking other work). Orphan detection should focus on dependency blocking, not just 'unpinned' status.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.

title: Deacon Kernel: event processing molecule architecture
description:
Extend the Deacon from "health orchestrator" to "event processing kernel" that runs a 
molecule (rounds) each wake cycle, like an OS kernel scheduler.

## Core Insight

The Deacon already has:
- Wake cycle (daemon poke, timer, lifecycle request)
- Mail as event queue
- Health scanning
- Lifecycle processing

But it is REACTIVE. This epic makes it PROACTIVE with a structured molecule:

```
Deacon Wake
├── Step 0: Session Check (should I cycle myself?)
├── Step 1: Health Scan (Mayor, Witnesses, Crew, Refineries)
├── Step 2: Lifecycle Processing (cycle/restart/shutdown requests)
├── Step 3: Plugin Execution (scheduled, event-triggered, human-requested)
├── Step 4: Event Callbacks (timers, subscriptions)
└── Step 5: Heartbeat + Wait
```

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Session cycling first** - Token costs are quadratic with session length.
   Deacon should aggressively cycle to fresh sessions. First step of every
   wake is "do I need a new session?" based on context budget.

2. **Pinned bead with marching orders** - A pinned bead (like gt prime for
   agents) defines the Deacon's rounds molecule. This is the Deacon's
   "kernel" - its operating loop.

3. **Keepalive file for daemon quieting** - Instead of daemon tmux-poking
   the Deacon (which interrupts work), Deacon writes a keepalive file.
   Daemon reads it and backs off. Worst case: Deacon forgets, gets one
   extra heartbeat it squelches.

4. **Molecule-based rounds** - The wake cycle becomes a molecule with steps.
   Each step can have plugins (inline attention). Steps can be added/modified
   by updating the pinned bead.

## Architecture

```
Go Daemon (minimal, dumb)
├── Reads {townRoot}/deacon/keepalive.json
├── If fresh: do nothing
├── If stale: poke Deacon (fallback)
└── Process lifecycle requests (still daemon's job)

Deacon (Claude agent, smart)
├── Wakes: poke, timer, mail event
├── Writes keepalive (quiets daemon for duration of rounds)
├── Runs rounds molecule:
│   ├── session-check: cycle if context budget low
│   ├── health-scan: check agents, remediate
│   ├── lifecycle: process requests
│   ├── plugins: run scheduled/triggered plugins
│   ├── events: process timer/event callbacks
│   └── complete: update heartbeat, wait
└── Reads marching orders from pinned bead
```

## Relation to Existing Work

- Extends gt-5af (Deacon infrastructure) - CLOSED
- Relates to gt-axz (Plugin architecture) - P3
- Fits into phase3-deacon of gt-ngpz (Christmas Plan)
- Enables gt-976 (Crew lifecycle) as part of health-scan step

title: Messaging infrastructure: lists, queues, and channels
description:
## Problem

Current messaging is point-to-point only:
- Mail: A → B (durable, polling)
- Nudge: A → B (ephemeral, real-time)

No support for broadcast, work queues, or pub/sub patterns.

## Design

### Addressing Syntax

| Prefix | System | Resolution | Storage | Claim? |
|--------|--------|------------|---------|--------|
| `agent/` | Mail | Direct | Recipient inbox | N/A |
| `@group` | Mail | Dynamic (filesystem) | Fan-out (N copies) | No |
| `list:name` | Mail | Static config | Fan-out (N copies) | No |
| `queue:name` | Mail | Static config | Shared (1 copy) | Yes |
| `announce:name` | Mail | Static config | Shared (1 copy) | No |
| `#channel` | Nudge | Dynamic (tmux) | None (ephemeral) | No |

### Dynamic Aliases

- `@rig/gastown` → scan ~/gt/gastown/ for agent dirs (witness, refinery, crew/*, polecats/*)
- `@town` → scan ~/gt/ for all agent dirs
- `@witnesses` → for each rig, include <rig>/witness
- `@crew/gastown` → scan ~/gt/gastown/crew/*
- `#rig/gastown` → scan tmux for gastown/* sessions
- `#town` → scan tmux for all Gas Town sessions

**Mail** resolves against filesystem (agents that exist)
**Channels** resolve against tmux (agents that are running)

### Static Config

Location: `~/gt/config/` (JSON format, machine-edited)

```json
// lists.json
{
  "oncall": ["mayor/", "gastown/witness", "beads/witness"],
  "cleanup/gastown": ["gastown/witness", "deacon/"]
}
```

### Work Queue Semantics

- `gt mail send queue:cleanup/gastown -s "Task" -m "..."`
- `bd update <msg-id> --claim` → atomic claim (sets assignee + in_progress)
- If already claimed, returns error "already claimed by X"

### Use Cases

1. **Polecat spawn**: `gt mail send @rig/gastown` → Witness + Deacon both notified
2. **Polecat cleanup**: `gt mail send queue:cleanup/gastown` → first to claim handles it
3. **Town broadcast**: `gt mail send @town -s "Handoff now"` → everyone gets copy
4. **Real-time alert**: `gt channel publish #witnesses "Swarm incoming"`

## Implementation Tasks

1. Create ~/gt/config/ directory structure
2. Implement dynamic alias resolution (filesystem scan)
3. Implement static list lookup (config/lists.json)
4. Add fan-out at send time for @/list: addresses
5. Implement queue: with shared storage
6. Add `bd update --claim` for work queue semantics
7. Implement channel resolution (tmux scan)
8. Add `gt channel publish` command

title: Create mol-refinery-patrol with test failure gates
description:
## Problem

The Refinery role lacks:
1. A formal patrol molecule (Deacon has mol-deacon-patrol)
2. Engineer identity/philosophy guidance
3. Structural enforcement of failure handling (not just documentation)

When tests fail during merge processing, the current guidance doesn't prevent 'disavowal' - noting a problem exists and proceeding without tracking it.

## The Structural Solution

Create `mol-refinery-patrol` with **verification gates** that make disavowal structurally impossible:

```markdown
## Molecule: mol-refinery-patrol

## Step: inbox-check
Check mail for MR submissions, escalations, messages.
Process any urgent items first.

## Step: queue-scan
Fetch remote, identify polecat branches waiting.
If queue empty, skip to context-check.
Track branch list for this cycle.
Needs: inbox-check

## Step: process-branch
Pick next branch. Rebase on current main.
If rebase conflicts: notify polecat, skip to next branch.
Needs: queue-scan

## Step: run-tests
Run go test ./...
Track results (pass/fail count).
Needs: process-branch

## Step: handle-failures
**GATE**: If tests passed, this step auto-completes.
If tests failed:
- Diagnose: branch regression or pre-existing?
- Branch regression → abort, notify polecat
- Pre-existing → EITHER fix OR \`bd create --type=bug\`
**VERIFY**: Fix committed OR bead filed before proceeding.
Needs: run-tests

## Step: merge-push
Merge to main (ff-only preferred).
Push immediately.
Delete polecat branch.
Needs: handle-failures

## Step: loop-check
More branches? Return to process-branch.
Otherwise continue to summary.
Needs: merge-push

## Step: generate-summary
Summarize cycle: branches processed, tests results, issues filed.
Needs: loop-check

## Step: context-check
Check context usage.
If high: write handoff, prepare for burn/respawn.
Needs: generate-summary

## Step: burn-or-loop
If context LOW and queue non-empty: loop (return to queue-scan)
If context HIGH or queue empty: burn and exit
Needs: context-check
```

## Implementation Tasks

### 1. Add RefineryPatrolMolecule() to builtin_molecules.go
- Copy pattern from DeaconPatrolMolecule
- Include all steps with proper `Needs:` dependencies
- Emphasize handle-failures gate in description

### 2. Update Refinery CLAUDE.md
Add sections:
- **The Engineer Mindset** (identity/philosophy)
- **The Scotty Test** (Would Scotty walk past this?)
- **Patrol Molecule** reference (mol-refinery-patrol)
- **Test Failure Protocol** (explicit decision tree)

### 3. Create prompts/roles/refinery.md
- Follow pattern of deacon.md
- Include patrol execution loop diagram
- Reference the molecule

### 4. Consider mol-witness-patrol
- Witness has detailed heartbeat protocol but no formal molecule
- Similar pattern could apply

## Why This Matters

GUPP: 'If you have work on your hook, you have to run it.'
The patrol molecule puts failure handling ON THE HOOK as a mandatory step.
You can't skip handle-failures to get to merge-push.
The structure enforces good behavior.

## Related
- gt-7919: Fix failing beads tests (discovered during this session)
- mol-deacon-patrol (existing pattern to follow)
- docs/molecular-chemistry.md (chemistry concepts)
- docs/wisp-architecture.md (wisp vs mol decision)

title: Check Witness and Refinery health
description:
Check Witness and Refinery health for each rig.

**ZFC Principle**: You (Claude) make the judgment call about what is "stuck" or "unresponsive" - there are no hardcoded thresholds in Go. Read the signals, consider context, and decide.

For each rig, run:
```bash
gt witness status <rig>
gt refinery status <rig>
```

**Signals to assess:**

| Component | Healthy Signals | Concerning Signals |
|-----------|-----------------|-------------------|
| Witness | State: running, recent activity | State: not running, no heartbeat |
| Refinery | State: running, queue processing | Queue stuck, merge failures |

**Tracking unresponsive cycles:**

Maintain in your patrol state (persisted across cycles):
```
health_state:
  <rig>:
    witness:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
    refinery:
      unresponsive_cycles: 0
      last_seen_healthy: <timestamp>
```

**Decision matrix** (you decide the thresholds based on context):

| Cycles Unresponsive | Suggested Action |
|---------------------|------------------|
| 1-2 | Note it, check again next cycle |
| 3-4 | Attempt restart: gt witness restart <rig> |
| 5+ | Escalate to Mayor with context |

**Restart commands:**
```bash
gt witness restart <rig>
gt refinery restart <rig>
```

**Escalation:**
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Health: <rig> <component> unresponsive" \
  -m "Component has been unresponsive for N cycles. Restart attempts failed.
      Last healthy: <timestamp>
      Error signals: <details>"
```

Reset unresponsive_cycles to 0 when component responds normally.

The witness patrol formula expects polecat agent beads to have:

  hook_bead: <current-work-id>

This field is used by the witness to see what the polecat is working on.

But looking at the code, hook_bead is never set:

1. Polecat agent bead created (polecat/manager.go:167-170) - no hook_bead
2. reportAgentState called (prime.go:1067) - passes nil for hookBead
3. UpdateAgentState preserves existing hook_bead if nil (beads.go:633-635)

Since hook_bead starts empty and is never updated, the witness cannot use
agent beads to see what polecats are working on.

## Found in commit

f3a6ef6 (feat: Witness reads polecat state from agent beads)

## Related to

- gt-0lop3 (Agent state lifecycle incomplete for polecats)

## Suggested fix

When a polecat is assigned work (via gt sling or similar), update the agent
bead's hook_bead field:

  bd.UpdateAgentState(agentID, 'running', &hookBeadID)

title: Witness session cycling and handoff
description:
Add session cycling and handoff protocol to Witness CLAUDE.md template.

## Session Cycling Protocol

```markdown
## Session Cycling

Your context will fill over long swarms. Proactively cycle when:
- Running for many hours
- Losing track of which workers you've checked
- Responses getting slower
- About to start complex operation

### Handoff Protocol

1. **Capture current state**:
```bash
town list .           # Worker states
town all beads        # Pending verifications  
town inbox            # Unprocessed messages
```

2. **Compose handoff note**:
```
[HANDOFF_TYPE]: witness_cycle
[TIMESTAMP]: <now>
[RIG]: <rig>

## Active Workers
<list workers and status>

## Pending Verifications
<workers signaled done but not verified>

## Recent Actions
<last 3-5 actions>

## Warnings/Notes
<anything next session should know>

## Next Steps
<what should happen next>
```

3. **Send handoff**:
```bash
town mail send <rig>/witness -s "Session Handoff" -m "<note>"
```

4. **Exit cleanly**: End session, daemon spawns fresh one.

### On Fresh Session Start

1. Check for handoff: `town inbox | grep "Session Handoff"`
2. If found, read it and resume from handoff state
3. If not found, do full status check
```

## Implementation

Add to WITNESS_CLAUDE.md template.

title: Molecule format bridge: convert embedded markdown to child issues
description:
## Problem

Two molecule formats exist:
1. **Old (gastown builtin)**: Steps embedded as markdown in Description field, parsed by ParseMoleculeSteps()
2. **New (bd mol)**: Steps as child issues in proper beads DAG

The daemon's InstantiateMolecule() uses the old format. bd mol spawn uses the new format.

## Options

### Option A: Require child issues (new format)
- Update daemon to use bd mol spawn instead of InstantiateMolecule
- Deprecate embedded markdown format
- Pro: One format, simpler
- Con: Breaking change for existing molecules

### Option B: Build a bridge
- In InstantiateMolecule, detect format:
  - If Description has ## Step: markers → parse to child issues
  - If issue has children with template label → use directly
- Convert old format to new format on instantiation
- Pro: Backward compatible
- Con: More complexity

## Recommendation

Option B - build the bridge. On instantiation, convert markdown steps to child issues. This unifies execution while preserving authoring flexibility.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

bonded_to: gt-n8s1
bonded_ref: arm-toast
bonded_at: 2025-12-23T10:00:00Z

description:
CLI commands for managing the Refinery agent.

## Commands

```bash
gt refinery start <rig>      # Start refinery for a rig
gt refinery stop <rig>       # Stop refinery
gt refinery status <rig>     # Show refinery status
gt refinery queue <rig>      # Show merge queue
```

## gt refinery start

Starts the Refinery daemon for the specified rig.

Options:
- --foreground: Run in foreground (default: background)
- --auto-merge: Enable auto-merge (default: from config)

## gt refinery stop

Stops a running Refinery. Gracefully finishes current MR if processing.

## gt refinery status

Shows:
- Running state (running/stopped)
- Current MR being processed (if any)
- Queue length
- Last merge time
- Recent activity

## gt refinery queue

Shows the merge queue:
```
Merge queue for 'wyvern':
  1. [pending] Toast/polecat-auth-fix (15m ago)
  2. [pending] Capable/polecat-new-feature (5m ago)
  
1 merged today, 0 rejected
```

## Implementation

Uses gt-ov2 (Refinery agent) for daemon functionality.

Crew workers (like joe, max) don't have patrol molecules keeping them fresh. When gt gets rebuilt, they have stale binaries that cause hangs and bugs.

## Problem

- Crew binaries get stale when gt is rebuilt elsewhere
- No automatic pull/rebase/rebuild on session start
- No standardized shutdown protocol (sync, push, handoff)

## Solution: mol-crew-session

A molecule template for crew sessions:

### Startup Phase
1. `git pull --rebase` - get latest code
2. `bd sync` - sync beads
3. `go build -o gt ./cmd/gt` - rebuild gt (if in gastown)
4. `gt prime` - load context

### Work Phase  
- Open-ended human interaction
- No molecule steps - just work until done

### Shutdown Phase
1. `git status` - check for uncommitted changes
2. `bd sync` - sync beads
3. `git push` - push code
4. Handoff if incomplete work

## Implementation

1. Define mol-crew-session in builtin_molecules.go
2. Update crew CLAUDE.md to reference the protocol
3. Optionally: gt prime auto-runs startup steps

- Consider: gt-3x0z.10 (Witness patrol molecules)

title: Haiku-based smart stuck detection
description:
Use Haiku to analyze tmux state when signals are ambiguous.

## When to Invoke

Only as escalation tier:
1. Keepalive is stale (> 2 min)
2. Tmux shows claude is running (not idle shell)
3. Heuristics can't determine state

## Prompt

Capture last 50 lines of tmux pane, ask Haiku:
'Is this Claude agent: WORKING | STUCK | IDLE | WAITING_FOR_HUMAN?'

## Cost

~$0.001 per check. At 1 check/min worst case = $0.06/hour.
In practice, most checks avoided by keepalive signal.

## Configuration

```toml
[daemon]
smart_detection = true
smart_model = "haiku"
smart_threshold = "2m"  # only check if stale > 2min
```

title: Implement handoffs using pinned beads
description:
Replace the current mail-based handoff system with pinned beads.

## Current Problem

Handoff messages get closed before the successor can read them because:
1. `gt mail read` auto-acks (closes) messages
2. `bd mail inbox` only shows open messages
3. Successor sees empty inbox

## Solution

Use pinned beads for handoffs:
- One pinned bead per role: `mayor-handoff`, `<rig>-refinery-handoff`, etc.
- Predecessor updates the content before cycling
- Successor reads on startup via `gt prime`
- Never closes - always available

## Implementation

### 1. Create handoff beads on first cycle
- `bd create --title='Mayor Handoff' --type=task --status=pinned --assignee=mayor`
- Store ID in role config or use well-known naming convention

### 2. Update gt handoff command
- Instead of `bd mail send`, update the pinned handoff bead
- `bd update <handoff-id> --description='...handoff content...'`

### 3. Update gt prime
- Read the role's handoff bead
- Display content to successor

title: gt mail: Cross-level routing is broken
description:
**Problem:**
When Mayor (at ~/gt) sends mail to a rig worker (gastown/crew/max), the message lands in town-level beads (~/.beads/) but the recipient checks rig-level beads (crew/max/.beads/).

**Reproduction:**
```bash
cd ~/gt
gt mail send gastown/crew/max -s 'Test' -m 'body'
# Message goes to ~/gt/.beads/ with prefix hq-*

cd ~/gt/gastown/crew/max  
gt mail inbox
# Does NOT see the message - it's looking in crew/max/.beads/
```

**Root cause:**
`findBeadsWorkDir()` walks up from CWD to find .beads. `Router.Send()` runs `bd create` in that directory. This means messages always go to the sender's beads, not the recipient's.

**Fix options:**
1. Route based on recipient address - if sending to rig/*, use that rig's .beads
2. Use a single shared beads database for all mail (simpler but less isolated)
3. Teach agents to check both levels (workaround, not fix)

**Related:**
- gt-ngu1: Pinned beads sorting (done but pointless if mail doesn't route)
- This blocks all cross-level mail functionality

title: Swarm state persistence: manifest + state + events
description:
Upgrade swarm persistence to match PGT pattern.

## Current State
Single .gastown/swarms.json with all swarms.

## Target State (per-swarm)
```
.gastown/swarms/
└── <swarm-id>/
    ├── manifest.json  # Immutable config
    ├── state.json     # Mutable progress
    ├── events.jsonl   # Audit log
    └── report.md      # Generated report
```

## File Schemas

### manifest.json (immutable after creation)
```json
{
  "id": "sw-1",
  "title": "Epic description",
  "epic_id": "gt-abc",
  "rig": "gastown",
  "base_commit": "abc123",
  "integration_branch": "swarm/sw-1",
  "target_branch": "main",
  "workers": ["Toast", "Nux"],
  "tasks": [{"id": "gt-xyz", "title": "..."}],
  "created_at": "2024-01-01T00:00:00Z"
}
```

### state.json (mutable)
```json
{
  "state": "active",
  "task_states": {
    "gt-xyz": {"state": "merged", "assignee": "Toast"}
  },
  "updated_at": "2024-01-01T01:00:00Z",
  "error": null
}
```

### events.jsonl (append-only audit)
```jsonl
{"event": "created", "ts": "...", "data": {...}}
{"event": "task_assigned", "ts": "...", "data": {...}}
{"event": "task_merged", "ts": "...", "data": {...}}
```

## Benefits
- Audit trail via events.jsonl
- Manifest immutability prevents corruption
- Cleaner separation of concerns
- Per-swarm isolation

## Migration
Keep backward compat with swarms.json during transition.

## Files to Modify
- internal/swarm/manager.go: Refactor persistence
- internal/cmd/swarm.go: SwarmStore → directory-based

- [ ] Per-swarm directory structure

title: Swarm beads naming convention and auto-filing
description:
Beads naming convention for swarm lifecycle events.

## Bead IDs

- swarm-started:<swarm-id>     # Filed when swarm begins
- swarm-task-merged:<swarm-id>:<task-id>  # Filed per task merge
- swarm-landed:<swarm-id>      # Filed when merged to main
- swarm-failed:<swarm-id>      # Filed on unrecoverable failure

## swarm-started Bead

Filed by: Mayor/Refinery at swarm creation
Contains:
- Swarm title and description
- List of tasks (issue IDs)
- List of workers (polecat names)
- Base commit SHA

## swarm-task-merged Bead

Filed by: Refinery after each successful merge
Contains:
- Task issue ID and title
- Polecat name
- Merge commit SHA
- Test results summary

## swarm-landed Bead

Filed by: Refinery after landing to main
Contains:
- Final merge commit SHA
- Stats: tasks completed, time taken
- List of all merged task beads
- Integration branch name (now deleted)

## swarm-failed Bead

Filed by: Refinery on unrecoverable failure
Contains:
- Failure reason
- Tasks merged vs not merged
- Recovery guidance

## Why Beads (not just mail)

- Persistent, queryable, synced to git
- Other agents can check status without mail
- Creates audit trail
- Works when agents offline

title: Remove Go-based witness patrol - Claude session is the executor
description:
## Problem

The witness has 1370 lines of Go code in internal/witness/manager.go that reimplements what mol-witness-patrol does:
- healthCheck() - polls polecats
- autoSpawnForReadyWork() - spawns polecats for ready issues  
- handleStuckPolecat() - nudge logic
- processShutdownRequests() - cleanup logic
- verifyPolecatState() - git state checks

This is backwards. The molecule should drive the work, Claude should execute it.

## The Wrong Architecture (gt-59zd, now cancelled)

The cancelled gt-59zd tried to use molecules as 'tracking ledgers' for Go code:
- Go code runs patrol logic
- Molecule just records what Go did
- Duplicates work, adds complexity

## The Right Architecture

1. Witness runs as Claude session (via gt sling witness or tmux)
2. Claude executes mol-witness-patrol steps directly
3. No Go patrol loop needed
4. Molecule IS the executor, not bookkeeping

## Scope

1. Remove patrol-related functions from manager.go:
   - run(), checkAndProcess(), healthCheck()
   - handleStuckPolecat(), getNudgeCount(), recordNudge()
   - processShutdownRequests(), verifyPolecatState()
   - autoSpawnForReadyWork(), etc.

2. Keep session management functions:
   - Start(), Stop(), Status() - for starting/stopping Claude session
   - State persistence for session identity

3. Update gt witness commands to use Claude session model

4. Test that mol-witness-patrol executes correctly in Claude session

## Related

- gt-zde4: Fixed Witness CLAUDE.md to emphasize mol-following

## Overview

This epic tracks batch work coordination in GGT. Key insight: **work is a stream, not discrete swarms**.

There are no "swarm IDs" - the epic IS the grouping, the merge queue IS the coordination. "Swarming an epic" is colloquial for spawning multiple workers on its children.

## Architecture

- **Epics** group related work
- **Issues** are individual tasks  
- **Dependencies** encode ordering (multi-wave emerges automatically)
- **Merge queue** coordinates completed work
- **Workers** process issues independently

See Key Decision #11 in docs/architecture.md: "Work is a Stream (No Swarm IDs)"

## What This Epic Covers

1. Integration branch management for batch merges
2. Refinery semantic merge processing
3. Witness landing protocol (cleanup)
4. Report generation (epic-based, not swarm-ID-based)
5. Git safety auditing
6. Work reconciliation

## What Was Removed

- Swarm IDs (sw-1, sw-2, etc.)
- Per-swarm directories (.gastown/swarms/<id>/)
- Swarm manifest/state/events files
- swarm-started/swarm-landed beads

These were redundant - beads already provides hierarchy, status, dependencies, and history.

## References

- Architecture: docs/architecture.md (Key Decision #11, Multi-Wave Work Processing)
- PGT: swarm/manager.py, swarm/landing.py (behavioral reference, but ignore swarm ID patterns)

title: Burn and respawn or loop
description:
Burn and let daemon respawn, or exit if context high.

Decision point at end of patrol cycle:

If context is LOW:
- Sleep briefly (avoid tight loop)
- Return to inbox-check step

If context is HIGH:
- Write state to persistent storage
- Exit cleanly
- Let the daemon orchestrator respawn a fresh Deacon

The daemon ensures Deacon is always running:
```bash
# Daemon respawns on exit
gt daemon status
```

This enables infinite patrol duration via context-aware respawning.

title: Patrol Lifecycle Completion
description:
Patrols complete their full cycle without wisp accumulation.

## Problem
Patrol wisps accumulate (73+ observed) because burn-or-loop step does not complete. This wastes storage and makes bd list noisy.

## Requirements
- Burn-or-loop step executes and burns completed wisps
- Fresh wisp instantiated for next patrol cycle  
- Wisp GC runs periodically as safety net (orphan-check step)
- Context cycling triggers gt handoff when budget exhausted
- No wisp accumulation over time

## Success Criteria
- bd wisp list shows fewer than 5 wisps at any time
- Patrols run indefinitely without intervention
- Context cycles cleanly produce handoff mail

This is the foundation for all autonomous patrol work.

title: Standardize session end: gt handoff for all roles
description:
## Summary

Standardize session ending across all agent roles to use `gt handoff` as the canonical command. This is critical for the beads propulsion cycle - turning agent sessions from pets into cattle.

## Current State (Inconsistent)

| Role | Current Guidance | Command |
|------|-----------------|---------|
| Mayor | Manual mail send | `gt mail send mayor/ -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Crew | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/crew/<name> -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Witness | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/witness -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Refinery | Manual mail send | `gt mail send <rig>/refinery -s 'HANDOFF:...' -m '...'` |
| Deacon | Exit on high context | (implicit) |
| Polecat | `gt done` | `gt done [--exit TYPE]` |

## Target State (Unified)

All roles use `gt handoff`:
- `gt handoff` - Hand off current session to fresh instance
- `gt handoff -s 'context' -m 'details'` - Hand off with custom message
- For polecats: `gt handoff` internally calls `gt done`

## Changes Required

### 1. Code Changes
- [ ] Update `gt handoff` to detect polecat role and call `gt done` internally
- [ ] Consider adding `--exit` flag to `gt handoff` for polecat compatibility

### 2. CLAUDE.md Updates (gastown)
- [ ] ~/gt/CLAUDE.md (Mayor)
- [ ] gastown/crew/max/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/crew/joe/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/witness/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] gastown/refinery/CLAUDE.md (and rig/)
- [ ] deacon/CLAUDE.md

### 3. CLAUDE.md Updates (beads)
- [ ] beads/mayor/rig/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/crew/dave/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/crew/zoey/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/witness/CLAUDE.md
- [ ] beads/refinery/CLAUDE.md (and rig/)

### 4. Architecture Docs
- [ ] docs/patrol-system-design.md
- [ ] gastown/mayor/rig/docs/prompts.md
- [ ] gastown/mayor/rig/docs/session-management.md

## New Session End Checklist (Universal)

```
# SESSION CLOSE PROTOCOL

[ ] 1. git status              (check uncommitted changes)
[ ] 2. git add <files>         (stage changes)
[ ] 3. git commit -m '...'     (commit with issue ID)
[ ] 4. bd sync                 (sync beads)
[ ] 5. git push                (push to remote - CRITICAL)
[ ] 6. gt handoff              (hand off to fresh session)
       OR gt handoff -s 'Context' -m 'Details for next session'
```

## Why This Matters

The handoff mechanism is what turns agent sessions from **pets** (precious, long-lived) into **cattle** (disposable, replaceable). At any time, any agent can:
1. Send itself a detailed handoff mail (or sling itself a mol)
2. System shuts them down and restarts them
3. Fresh session runs priming and reads mail
4. Work continues seamlessly

This enables:
- Unlimited context through automatic cycling
- Clean recovery from any state
- Consistent behavior across all roles
- Simplified agent instructions

title: Deacon session cycling: first step of rounds
description:
First step of every Deacon wake cycle: check if a fresh session is needed.

## Why First

Token costs are quadratic with session length. A Deacon running for hours
accumulates massive context. Better to cycle early and often.

## Implementation

At wake, before doing anything else:

1. Check context budget estimate (conversation turns, tool calls, etc.)
2. If budget is low (e.g., >50% consumed), request cycle:
   - Write handoff mail to self with current state
   - Request lifecycle: cycle via daemon
   - Daemon kills session, starts fresh
   - New session reads handoff mail, continues

## Decision Criteria

- Conversation turns > N (configurable, default 50?)
- Explicit "context feels heavy" signal from Claude
- Time since last cycle > M hours (configurable, default 4?)
- Forced cycle on certain events (e.g., major config change)

## State to Preserve in Handoff

- Current health status
- Pending lifecycle requests (in flight)
- Plugin state (last run times, outcomes)
- Any active timers

## Relation to Daemon

The Deacon requests its own cycle via the same lifecycle mechanism:
```
gt mail send deacon/ -s "LIFECYCLE: deacon/ requesting cycle" -m "..."
```

Daemon sees this, kills gt-deacon session, respawn loop restarts it.

title: Add role-specific subcommands that delegate to core commands (agent UX)
description:
## Problem

Agents naturally guess command patterns like:
- `gt witness nudge <polecat>`
- `gt polecat nudge <name>`
- `gt crew restart <member>`

But these don't exist - the actual commands are:
- `gt nudge <session> <message>`
- `gt polecat reset <name>`

This creates friction in agent UX. Agents shouldn't have to memorize the 'correct' command structure.

## Proposal

Add subcommands to each role that delegate to core commands with argument reordering:

```
gt witness nudge furiosa "Start working"
  → gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Start working"

gt polecat nudge gastown/furiosa "Check mail"
  → gt nudge gt-gastown-furiosa "Check mail"

gt crew nudge gastown/max "Wake up"
  → gt nudge gt-crew-gastown-max "Wake up"
```

## Benefits

1. **Discoverable**: Agents explore `gt witness --help` and find nudge
2. **Lenient**: Multiple valid ways to express the same intent
3. **Role-contextual**: Commands under the role namespace feel natural
4. **Extensible**: Pattern works for future subcommands (status, reset, etc.)

## Implementation

Each role command (witness, polecat, crew, refinery) gets thin wrapper subcommands:

```go
// In witness.go
witnessCmd.AddCommand(&cobra.Command{
    Use:   "nudge <polecat> <message>",
    Short: "Nudge a polecat (delegates to gt nudge)",
    RunE: func(cmd *cobra.Command, args []string) error {
        session := formatSession(rig, args[0])
        return runNudge(session, args[1])
    },
})
```

## Future Candidates

Other subcommands to add as role-specific aliases:
- `gt polecat status <name>` (already exists, good pattern)
- `gt witness check <polecat>` → trigger a manual check
- `gt refinery merge <mr-id>` → process specific MR
- `gt crew send <member> <message>` → mail to crew member

title: Patrol exponential backoff for cost savings
description:
Agent-side backoff state tracking in patrol molecules.

## State

Each patrol agent tracks:
- current_interval: current sleep duration (starts at base)
- idle_cycles: count of cycles with no work found

## Backoff Logic

```
on await-signal timeout (no nudge):
    idle_cycles++
    current_interval = min(base * 2^idle_cycles, max_interval)

on nudge received:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
    wake immediately

on work found:
    idle_cycles = 0
    current_interval = base
```

## Where State Lives

Options:
A. Agent bead fields (persistent across sessions)
B. In-memory during patrol (resets on restart)
C. Wisp fields (ephemeral but survives handoff)

Option B is simplest - backoff resets when agent restarts anyway.

## Depends On

- gt-l6ro3.3: await-signal step type

- `mol sling` creates a fresh instance for execution

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

bonded_to: gt-zq7f
bonded_ref: arm-toast

title: gt nudge doesn't work with crew addresses
description:
## Bug

`gt nudge beads/crew/dave "message"` fails because it uses the polecat session manager which produces wrong session names.

## Expected
Session name: `gt-beads-crew-dave` (hyphen)

## Actual  
Session name: `gt-beads-crew/dave` (slash, from polecat manager)

## Root Cause

In nudge.go line 46-57, parseAddress returns polecatName=`crew/dave`, then SessionName keeps the slash.

## Fix

Detect `crew/` prefix and use crewSessionName() instead.

title: Standardize wisp creation syntax across role templates
description:

```bash

bd update <wisp-id> --status=pinned --assignee=deacon

**Witness template (BROKEN - see gt-xxx):**
```bash
bd mol wisp mol-witness-patrol --assignee={{ .RigName }}/witness

All patrol roles should use the same two-step pattern:
```bash
bd mol wisp create mol-<role>-patrol
bd update <wisp-id> --status=pinned --assignee=<identity>

Or we should add `--assignee` flag to `bd mol wisp` (file in beads repo if preferred).

title: Ephemeral patrol molecules leaking into beads
description:
## Problem

Ephemeral patrol orchestration molecules (e.g., mol-deacon-patrol, wisp step issues) keep appearing in bd ready output in gastown beads.

These are ephemeral/wisp issues that should:
1. Never be synced to the beads-sync branch
2. Live only in .beads-wisp/ (ephemeral storage)
3. Be squashed to digests, not persisted as regular beads

## Examples found

- gt-wisp-6ue: mol-deacon-patrol
- gt-pacdm: mol-deacon-patrol  
- gt-wisp-mpm: Check own context limit
- gt-wisp-lkc: Clean dead sessions

## Investigation needed

1. Where are these being created? (gt mol bond? manual bd create?)
2. Why are they using the gt- prefix instead of staying ephemeral?
3. Is the wisp storage (.beads-wisp/) being used correctly?
4. Is bd sync accidentally picking up ephemeral issues?

## Expected behavior

Patrol molecules and their steps should be ephemeral and never appear in bd ready or bd list.

Moved from bd-exy3.

title: Nudge newly spawned polecats
description:
Nudge newly spawned polecats that are ready for input.

When polecats are spawned, their Claude session takes 10-20 seconds to initialize.
The spawn command returns immediately without waiting. This step finds spawned
polecats that are now ready and sends them a trigger to start working.

```bash
# For each rig with polecats
for rig in gastown beads; do
    gt polecats $rig
    # For each working polecat, check if Claude is ready
    # Use tmux capture-pane to look for "> " prompt
done
```

For each ready polecat that hasn't been triggered yet:
1. Send "Begin." to trigger UserPromptSubmit hook
2. The hook injects mail, polecat sees its assignment
3. Mark polecat as triggered in state

Use WaitForClaudeReady from tmux package (polls for "> " prompt).
Timeout: 60 seconds per polecat. If not ready, try again next cycle.

title: Deacon patrol wisps should use town beads, not gastown rig beads
description:
## Problem

The deacon is a town-level role but stores patrol wisps in gastown/mayor/rig/.beads/ (see internal/cmd/prime.go:691). This fails for users who don't have the gastown rig installed.

## Correct Architecture

Deacon -> ~/gt/.beads-wisp/ (town-level, no rig dependency)

Town-level ephemeral work (deacon patrols) should use town wisp storage, just like rig-level ephemeral work (witness/refinery patrols) uses rig wisp storage.

## Implementation Tasks

### 1. Town Setup (gt install / gt town init)

- Create ~/gt/.beads-wisp/ directory during town initialization
- Initialize as git repo (for local commits, not synced)
- Add config.yaml with wisp: true
- Ensure .beads-wisp/ is gitignored at town level

Files:
- internal/cmd/install.go (or equivalent town init)
- internal/town/manager.go (if exists)

### 2. Rig Setup (gt rig init)

Already creates <rig>/.beads-wisp/ - verify this is working:
- internal/rig/manager.go:375 (beadsDir := filepath.Join(rigPath, ".beads-wisp"))
- internal/rig/manager.go:394 (ensureGitignoreEntry)

### 3. Deacon Code Fixes

Update deacon to use town wisp storage:
- internal/cmd/prime.go:691 - change rigBeadsDir to townWispDir
- internal/cmd/sling.go - route deacon wisps to town level
- internal/daemon/daemon.go - any deacon-specific wisp handling

### 4. gt doctor Checks

Add/update doctor checks for wisp directories:
- internal/doctor/wisp_check.go - already checks rig wisps
- Add TownWispCheck to verify ~/gt/.beads-wisp/ exists
- Add TownWispGitCheck to verify it is a valid git repo
- Update existing checks to handle both town and rig levels

Files:
- internal/doctor/wisp_check.go (extend for town level)
- internal/doctor/checks.go (register new checks)

### 5. Documentation

- docs/beads-data-plane.md - already updated with three-tier architecture
- Verify wisp-architecture.md reflects town-level wisps

## Testing

1. Fresh gt install should create ~/gt/.beads-wisp/
2. gt doctor should pass with no rig installed
3. Deacon patrol should work without gastown rig
4. gt sling patrol deacon/ --wisp should route to town wisps

title: Polecats should auto-cleanup after MR submission
description:
Currently polecats must manually run 'gt handoff --shutdown' after completing work. This is error-prone and leaves stale polecats around.

## Desired Flow

1. Polecat completes work
2. Polecat runs 'gt mq submit' (or similar)
3. MR is added to integration queue
4. **Polecat automatically cleans up** (no manual handoff needed)

## Implementation Options

### Option A: mq submit triggers cleanup
In 'gt mq submit':
1. Submit MR to queue
2. Automatically run cleanup (same as gt handoff --shutdown)
3. Polecat session terminates

### Option B: Refinery triggers cleanup
When Refinery picks up MR:
1. Refinery processes MR
2. Sends message to Witness: 'CLEANUP: <polecat>'
3. Witness cleans up polecat

### Option C: Molecule-driven
Define cleanup as final phase of polecat-work molecule:
1. code → test → submit-mr → cleanup

## Note
This reinforces the ephemeral model: polecats exist only for the duration of a single task.

title: Polecat state tracking: Add mr_submitted and merged states
description:
Track polecat lifecycle state separate from session state.

## New States

| State | Meaning |
|-------|---------|
| active | Working on assigned issue |
| mr_submitted | MR submitted, waiting for merge |
| idle | No current work, session may be alive |
| merged | Work successfully merged by Refinery |
| retired | Session killed, worktree removed |

## Implementation

1. Add state field to polecat tracking (state.json or beads)
2. `gt polecat update <name> --state=<state>`
3. `gt polecat list` shows state column
4. State transitions:
   - active → mr_submitted (on gt mq submit)
   - mr_submitted → merged (on Refinery notification)
   - merged → retired (on worktree cleanup)

## Acceptance
- Polecat state tracked and queryable
- State transitions happen at correct lifecycle points
- `gt polecat list` shows current state

title: Day 4.3: Polecat self-manages session handoffs
description:
**REVISED**: Session cadence is polecat-managed, not mechanically forced by Witness.

Polecats decide when to cycle their own sessions:
1. Work through molecule steps sequentially in one session
2. Close each step as completed (bd close, for activity feed)
3. Self-initiate handoff when: context filling, logical chunk done, or stuck
4. Use: gt handoff -s 'Continuing molecule' -m '<context notes>'

If polecat forgets to handoff:
- Compaction will force it eventually
- Work continues from hook (molecule state preserved)
- No work is lost

Witness role changes:
- Does NOT force recycle between steps
- DOES monitor for stuck (long idle on same step)
- DOES use recycle for stuck recovery (not routine step transitions)
- DOES verify clean state before nuke

This is more ZFC-compliant: polecats report their own needs.

## @group Dynamic Resolution in Mail Router

Wire agent bead queries into mail router for @group addresses.

## Updated Approach (post agent-as-bead + Dogs)

Agent discovery uses bead queries:

```bash
bd list --type=agent --rig=gastown         # All agents in rig
bd list --type=agent --role_type=witness   # All witnesses
bd list --type=agent --role_type=dog       # All dogs
```

## Supported Patterns

| Pattern | Resolution | Scope |
|---------|------------|-------|
| `@rig/gastown` | `--rig=gastown` | All gastown agents |
| `@town` | `--rig=""` (no filter) | All town-level agents |
| `@witnesses` | `--role_type=witness` | All witnesses across rigs |
| `@crew/gastown` | `--role_type=crew --rig=gastown` | Gastown crew |
| `@dogs` | `--role_type=dog` | All Deacon dogs |
| `@overseer` | Special case (not bead query) | Human operator |

## Deliverables

1. Parse @group syntax in router
2. Resolve via `bd list --type=agent` queries
3. Fan-out at send time (N copies, one per recipient)
4. Special handling for `@overseer` (single recipient, uses overseer.json)

## @overseer Special Case

The overseer is the human operator - NOT an agent bead. Resolution:
- Load `mayor/overseer.json`
- Use `overseer/` as recipient address
- No bead query needed

## Dependencies
- Agent bead schema (gt-ikyo1) ✅ closed
- Dog agent beads need role_type=dog (new prereq)

- @dogs sends to all Deacon dogs

title: Interactive prompts for destructive operations
description:
Add interactive confirmations for destructive operations.

## Operations Needing Confirmation
- `gt swarm cancel` - Cancels active swarm
- `gt swarm land --force` - Force landing
- `gt polecat decommission` - Removes polecat
- `gt rig remove` - Removes rig
- `gt stop --all` - Stops all sessions
- `gt mail purge` - Permanently deletes mail

## Implementation Options

### Option 1: promptui library
```go
import "github.com/manifoldco/promptui"

prompt := promptui.Prompt{
    Label:     "Delete polecat Toast",
    IsConfirm: true,
}
result, err := prompt.Run()
```

### Option 2: Simple stdin
```go
func confirm(prompt string) bool {
    fmt.Printf("%s [y/N]: ", prompt)
    var response string
    fmt.Scanln(&response)
    return strings.ToLower(response) == "y"
}
```

## Bypass Flags
All confirmations skippable with --force or --yes:
```go
if !force && !confirm("Really cancel swarm?") {
    return nil
}
```

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Destructive ops prompt by default
- [ ] --force or --yes bypasses
- [ ] Clear prompt text explaining action
- [ ] Non-interactive mode (piped input) auto-fails

title: Refinery Role Definition
description:
You are the Refinery - merge queue processor for your rig. You process
completed polecat work, merging it to main one branch at a time with
sequential rebasing.

Your mission: Process the merge queue sequentially, rebasing each branch
atop the current baseline before merging.

default_molecule: mol-refinery-patrol
capabilities:
  - merge_queue_processing
  - sequential_rebase
  - conflict_resolution
  - verification_gates

## The Engineer Mindset

You are Scotty in the engine room. The merge queue is your warp core.

The Beads Promise: Work is never lost. If you discover ANY problem:
1. Fix it now (preferred if quick), OR
2. File a bead and proceed (tracked for cleanup crew)

There is NO third option. Never "disavow" by noting something exists and moving on.

The Scotty Test: Before proceeding past any failure, ask yourself:
"Would Scotty walk past a warp core leak because it existed before his shift?"

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by the mol-refinery-patrol molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Sequential Rebase Protocol

WRONG (parallel merge - causes conflicts):
  main -> branch-A (old main) + branch-B (old main) = CONFLICTS

RIGHT (sequential rebase):
  main -> merge A (rebased on main) -> merge B (rebased on main+A)

After every merge, main moves. Next branch MUST rebase on new baseline.

## Verification Gate

The handle-failures step is a verification gate:
- Tests PASSED: Gate satisfied, proceed to merge
- Tests FAILED (branch caused): Abort, notify polecat, skip branch
- Tests FAILED (pre-existing): MUST fix OR file bead - cannot proceed without

## Commands

### Patrol
- gt mol status - Check attached patrol
- bd ready / bd show / bd close - Step management
- bd mol spawn <mol> --wisp - Spawn patrol wisp

### Git Operations
- git fetch origin - Fetch all remote branches
- git branch -r | grep polecat - List polecat branches
- git rebase origin/main - Rebase on current main
- git push origin main - Push merged changes

### Communication
- gt mail inbox - Check for messages
- gt mail send <addr> -s "Subject" -m "Message" - Notify workers

title: Witness swarm landing protocol
description:
Witness responsibilities for swarm landing cleanup.

## Trigger

Witness receives "swarm-landed" mail from Refinery containing:
- swarm_id
- merge_commit
- action: "cleanup"

## Landing Protocol

### Phase 1: Preflight
Verify all polecat sessions stopped:
- Check tmux for active sessions
- Kill any remaining sessions
- Wait for graceful shutdown

### Phase 2: Git Audit
For each polecat in swarm:
- Check for uncommitted changes
- Check for unpushed commits
- Check for stashes
- Classify as "beads-only" (safe) or "code at risk"
- If code at risk: escalate, abort landing

### Phase 3: Cleanup
For each polecat:
- Clear state entry (mark as idle)
- Delete inbox (or archive)
- Delete worker branch (local + remote)

### Phase 4: Final Report
- Update swarm state to "landed"
- File landing report bead
- Mail Mayor with summary

## Code at Risk Handling

If git audit finds code at risk:
1. Abort cleanup for that polecat
2. Mail Mayor with details
3. Human intervention required

## Reference

PGT: swarm/landing.py (6-phase protocol), swarm/git_audit.py

title: Epic: Fix swarm orchestration - witness/refinery/polecat lifecycle
description:
## Problem Statement

The bd-9115 swarm execution required excessive manual intervention from Mayor. The witness, refinery, and polecat lifecycle components didn't coordinate automatically.

## What Should Have Happened

```
Mayor slings 6 beads to rig
    ↓
Polecats auto-spawn with synced beads, work pinned
    ↓
Polecats work autonomously
    ↓
Witness monitors progress, nudges stuck polecats
    ↓
Polecat completes → pushes branch → signals completion
    ↓
Refinery detects ready branch → rebases → merges → deletes branch
    ↓
Witness detects merge → nukes polecat worktree
    ↓
When all done → Witness notifies Mayor
```

## What Actually Happened

1. **gt sling failed to pin beads** - polecat worktrees had stale JSONL
2. **Manual intervention** - had to checkout latest JSONL, pin, nudge each polecat
3. **Witness was passive** - never nudged or checked on polecats
4. **Refinery waited for requests** - didn't detect completed branches
5. **Manual lifecycle** - Mayor had to close beads, nuke polecats
6. **Manual merge coordination** - had to mail refinery with merge order

## Root Cause: Branch Hysteresis

Polecat branches persist across runs and drift from main/beads-sync:
- `polecat/foo` created weeks ago from old main
- New work slung to `polecat/foo` 
- JSONL in branch doesn't have new beads
- Pin fails

## Open Questions

### Q1: Fresh branches per run?
Should each polecat spawn create a NEW branch from latest main/beads-sync?
```
gt sling bd-xxx rig
  → creates polecat/foo-20251227-1630 from origin/main
  → ensures JSONL is current
  → after merge, branch deleted forever
```
Pros: No drift, always current
Cons: Branch proliferation, naming complexity

### Q2: Rebase existing branches?
Or should we rebase persistent polecat branches before work?
```
gt sling bd-xxx rig/foo
  → git fetch origin
  → git rebase origin/main
  → now JSONL is current
```
Pros: Keeps simple naming
Cons: Rebase can fail with conflicts

### Q3: Just cherry-pick JSONL?
Minimal fix - grab latest JSONL before pinning:
```
git checkout origin/beads-sync -- .beads/issues.jsonl
bd import  # refresh DB
bd pin bd-xxx
```
Pros: Simple, surgical
Cons: Doesn't fix code drift, just beads

### Q4: Shared beads DB?
Could polecats share a DB (via symlink or sqlite over network)?
Pros: Always consistent
Cons: Locking complexity, daemon conflicts

### Q5: Who owns polecat lifecycle?
- Witness? (current assumption)
- Refinery? (after merge)
- gt sling? (on spawn)
- New "foreman" role?

## Proposed Solutions

See child issues for implementation details. Need to resolve open questions first.

gt peek {{polecat}}

- Progress on commits

Wait for SHUTDOWN signal from the polecat.

gt session kill {{polecat}}

```

Update beads state and close the lease.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

bonded_ref: arm-toast

title: BUG: gt done doesn't push branch to origin - work lost when worktree deleted
description:
## Problem

`gt done` creates a merge-request record in beads but **never pushes the branch to origin**.

When polecats are cleaned up (worktrees deleted), the branch is lost forever. The MR record exists but there's no actual branch to merge.

## Evidence

12 MQ items had `ready` status but no corresponding branches on origin. All polecat worktrees were deleted, losing all work.

## Impact

**CRITICAL**: All polecat work is silently lost unless polecats manually push (which they don't know to do).

## Fix

In `done.go`, before creating the MR:
1. `git push origin <branch>` to push the branch to remote
2. Only create MR record if push succeeds

## Location
`mayor/rig/internal/cmd/done.go:124-135`

title: gt rig add / gt doctor: patrol awareness and wiring
description:
## Problem

When a rig is installed or audited, we need to ensure all built-in patrols and role hooks are properly wired up.

## gt rig add Changes

When adding a rig, automatically:

1. **Create patrol molecules** for each role:
   - mol-deacon-patrol (town-level)
   - mol-witness-patrol (per-rig)
   - mol-refinery-patrol (per-rig)

2. **Set up hooks** that trigger patrols:
   - Deacon: daemon timer / heartbeat
   - Witness: daemon timer / polecat lifecycle events
   - Refinery: MR submission events / daemon timer

3. **Configure daemon** to manage these patrols:
   - Register patrol molecules in daemon config
   - Set up respawn behavior for each role

4. **Create plugin directories**:
   - ~/gt/plugins/ (town-level)
   - <rig>/plugins/ (rig-level, if needed)

## gt doctor Changes

Add patrol health checks:

### patrol-molecules-exist
- Verify mol-deacon-patrol, mol-witness-patrol, mol-refinery-patrol exist
- Check they parse correctly (valid steps, dependencies)

### patrol-hooks-wired
- Verify hooks trigger patrol execution
- Check daemon is configured to manage patrols

### patrol-not-stuck
- Detect wisps that have been in-progress too long
- Flag orphaned patrol molecules (no active session)

### patrol-plugins-accessible
- Verify plugin directories exist and are readable
- Check plugin frontmatter parses correctly

### patrol-roles-have-prompts
- Verify prompts/roles/*.md exist for each role
- Check they reference the correct patrol molecule

## Auto-fix

gt doctor --fix can:
- Create missing patrol molecules
- Wire up missing hooks
- Create plugin directories
- NOT restart stuck patrols (needs human decision)

## Related
- gt-7920 (mol-refinery-patrol)
- gt-7921 (await-work and plugin-run)
- docs/wisp-architecture.md

title: tmux link-window auto-selects new window, causing agent confusion
description:
## Summary

When running `gt crew at <other>` from inside a tmux session, the linked window auto-selects, causing the user to unknowingly switch agents.

## Root Cause

`internal/tmux/tmux.go:535-538` - `LinkWindow` doesn't use `-d` flag:
```go
_, err := t.run("link-window", "-s", source)  // Missing -d!
```

By default, `tmux link-window` selects the newly linked window.

## Reproduction

1. Be in Max's tmux session talking to Max
2. Ask Max to run `gt crew at joe`
3. Max creates Joe's session and links it
4. User is now in Joe's window without realizing it
5. Max appears to have 'disappeared'

## Fix

Add `-d` flag to prevent auto-selection:
```go
_, err := t.run("link-window", "-s", source, "-d")
```

## Related

- gt-09i4: Unify tmux session lifecycle (broader epic Max filed)

title: gt mq submit: creates task type instead of merge-request type

gt-n508: Merge: gt-70b3
Status: open
Priority: P1
Type: task      <-- WRONG, should be merge-request
...
Description:
type: merge-request   <-- Correct type is in description, not in actual type field

## Impact

## Fix

`gt mq submit` should set `--type merge-request` when creating the bead.

title: Mail system: message types and threading
description:
GGT mail system needs message types and threading like PGT.

## 1. Message Types
Add to internal/mail/types.go:
```go
type MessageType string
const (
    TypeTask         MessageType = "task"         // Required processing
    TypeScavenge     MessageType = "scavenge"     // Optional first-come work
    TypeNotification MessageType = "notification" // Informational
    TypeReply        MessageType = "reply"        // Response to message
)

// Update Message struct
type Message struct {
    // existing fields...
    Type     MessageType `json:"type"`
    ThreadID string      `json:"thread_id,omitempty"`
    ReplyTo  string      `json:"reply_to,omitempty"`
}
```

## 2. Priority Levels
Expand from 2 to 4:
```go
type Priority string
const (
    PriorityLow    Priority = "low"
    PriorityNormal Priority = "normal"
    PriorityHigh   Priority = "high"
    PriorityUrgent Priority = "urgent"
)
```

## 3. CLI Updates
internal/cmd/mail.go:
- Add --type flag to send: `gt mail send ... --type task`
- Add --reply-to flag: `gt mail send ... --reply-to <msg-id>`
- Add thread command: `gt mail thread <thread-id>`

## 4. Threading Logic
NewMessage() should auto-generate thread_id if not a reply.
Reply messages inherit thread_id from original.

## Files to Modify
- internal/mail/types.go: Add types, expand Priority
- internal/mail/mailbox.go: Thread filtering
- internal/cmd/mail.go: CLI flags and thread command

## PGT Reference
gastown-py/src/gastown/mail/message.py

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Messages have type field (default: notification)
- [ ] 4 priority levels supported
- [ ] Reply creates thread with shared thread_id
