title: Document Overseer role (human operator)
description:
Document the Overseer role in Gas Town architecture.

## The Overseer

The **Overseer** is the human operator of Gas Town. Not an agent - a person.

## Responsibilities

| Area | Overseer Does | Mayor/Agents Do |
|------|---------------|-----------------|
| Strategy | Define project goals | Execute toward goals |
| Priorities | Set priority order | Work in priority order |
| Escalations | Final decision on stuck work | Escalate to Overseer |
| Resources | Provision machines | Use allocated resources |
| Quality | Review & approve swarm output | Produce output |
| Operations | Run gt commands, monitor dashboards | Do the work |

## Key Interactions

### Overseer → Mayor
- Start/stop Mayor sessions
- Direct Mayor via conversation
- Review Mayor recommendations
- Approve cross-rig decisions

### Mayor → Overseer (Escalations)
- Stuck workers after retries
- Resource decisions (add machines, polecats)
- Ambiguous requirements
- Architecture decisions

## Operating Cadence

Typical Overseer workflow:
1. Morning: Check status, review overnight work
2. During day: Monitor, respond to escalations, adjust priorities
3. End of day: Review progress, plan next batch

## Commands for Overseers

```bash
gt status              # Quick health check
gt doctor              # Detailed diagnostics  
gt doctor --fix        # Auto-repair issues
gt inbox               # Messages from agents
gt stop --all          # Emergency halt
```

## Documentation Updates

Add to docs/architecture.md:
- Overseer section under Agent Roles
- Clarify Mayor reports to Overseer
- Add Overseer to workflow diagrams

title: Async Coordination Gates
description:
Agents wait for external events without polling.

## Problem
Agents cannot wait for external conditions (CI completion, human approval, timers) without wasteful polling or losing state on handoff.

## Requirements
- Gate issue type in beads (type=gate)
- bd gate create --await timer:5m / gh:run:123 / human:approve / mail:pattern
- Deacon evaluates pending gates each patrol cycle
- Agents park work on gate, resume when condition met
- Gate timeout and notification

## Gate Types
- timer:<duration> - Simple delay (5m, 1h, 24h)
- gh:run:<id> - GitHub Actions run completion
- gh:pr:<id> - PR merged/closed  
- human:<prompt> - Human approval required
- mail:<pattern> - Wait for mail matching pattern

## Success Criteria
- Agent can create gate and suspend work
- Deacon wakes agent when gate condition met
- Gates survive session cycling

Consolidates gt-31eg. Parallel work with no dependencies.

title: gt commands should follow .beads/redirect
description:
## Problem

`gt sling` (and likely other gt commands) don't follow the `.beads/redirect` file that `bd` uses to share beads across clones.

This caused confusion during the v0.39.0 release: molecules were poured successfully to mayor/rig's beads (via redirect), but `gt sling` couldn't find them because it was looking in the crew clone's local .beads/.

## Expected Behavior

All `gt` commands that interact with beads should follow the redirect mechanism that `bd` uses.

## Affected Commands (likely)

- `gt sling`
- `gt hook`  
- `gt mol status`
- `gt mol attach`
- Any command that shells out to `bd show` or similar

## Solution

When `gt` needs to find the beads directory, check for `.beads/redirect` and follow it, same as `bd` does.

title: Wisp directory and format
description:
Define and implement the .beads-wisp directory structure.

## Directory Structure

```
<clone>/.beads-wisp/
  hook-<agent>.wisp.yaml     # Slung work for this agent
  patrol-<id>.wisp.yaml      # Patrol cycle state (future)
```

## Wisp File Format

```yaml
type: slung-work | patrol-cycle
created_at: ISO timestamp
created_by: entity who created it

# For slung-work:
bead_id: gt-xxx
context: optional message

# For patrol-cycle (future):
formula: mol-deacon-patrol
current_step: inbox-check
step_states: {...}
```

## Key Properties

- NOT git tracked (.beads-wisp/ in .gitignore)
- Ephemeral - burned after use
- Local to each clone
- Fast writes (no sync needed)

## Implementation

- internal/wisp/dir.go - Directory creation/management
- internal/wisp/types.go - Wisp type definitions
- internal/wisp/io.go - Read/write operations

title: Move mol run semantics from bd into gt spawn
description:
Currently gt spawn shells out to bd mol run for the pour+assign+pin combo. This blurs the architectural boundary between bd (data layer) and gt (orchestration layer).

## Current State
- bd mol run = bd pour + bd update --status=in_progress + bd pin --for me
- gt spawn calls: exec.Command("bd", "mol", "run", ...)

## Proposed Change
Move the combo logic into gt spawn directly:
1. gt spawn calls bd pour (create issues from template)
2. gt spawn calls bd update --status=in_progress (claim work)
3. gt spawn calls bd pin (set pinned flag)
4. gt spawn does session/tmux orchestration

This keeps bd as pure data operations and gt as the orchestration layer.

## Why
- Cleaner separation of concerns
- bd mol run feels like orchestration but it's in the data layer
- gt should own the "start a workflow" semantics

## Coordination
beads side will deprecate bd mol run once gt no longer depends on it.

title: Outpost/Worker interfaces: Core abstractions for remote compute
description:
## Overview

Define the core interfaces that all outpost types implement.

## Interfaces

```go
type OutpostType string
const (
    OutpostLocal    OutpostType = "local"
    OutpostSSH      OutpostType = "ssh"
    OutpostCloudRun OutpostType = "cloudrun"
)

type Outpost interface {
    Name() string
    Type() OutpostType
    MaxWorkers() int
    ActiveWorkers() int
    Spawn(issue string, config WorkerConfig) (Worker, error)
    Workers() []Worker
    Ping() error
    SendMail(worker string, msg Message) error  // optional
}

type Worker interface {
    ID() string
    Outpost() string
    Status() WorkerStatus  // idle, working, done, failed
    Issue() string
    Attach() error         // for interactive outposts
    Logs() (io.Reader, error)
    Stop() error
}

type WorkerConfig struct {
    RigPath    string
```

title: Refactor: Eliminate state.json, use beads assignee field for polecat state
description:
## Problem

state.json in each polecat worktree duplicates data that should be in beads:
- `issue` field duplicates assignment (should be issue.assignee)
- `state` field duplicates status (derivable from issue.status)
- `name/rig/branch/clone_path` are all derivable from filesystem/git

This violates 'Beads as the data plane' (HOP Decision 001).

## Current State

```json
{
  "name": "Angharad",        // Derivable: basename(cwd)
  "rig": "gastown",          // Derivable: parent dir name
  "state": "working",        // Should be: issue.status
  "clone_path": "/path",     // Derivable: cwd
  "branch": "polecat/X",     // Derivable: git branch
  "issue": "gt-xyz",         // Should be: issue.assignee
  "timestamps": "..."        // Should be in beads history
}
```

## Target State

**Polecat identity**: Derived from worktree path
**Polecat assignment**: `issue.assignee = 'gastown/Angharad'`
**Polecat state**: Derived from issue.status (in_progress = working, closed = done)
**Polecat existence**: Worktree directory exists

## Benefits

1. Single source of truth (no sync issues)
2. Queryable: `bd list --assignee=gastown/Angharad`
3. History tracking via beads
4. Cross-agent coordination via beads sync
5. Simpler code (no state file management)

## Implementation

1. Update `gt spawn` to set issue.assignee instead of writing state.json
2. Update polecat list/status commands to query beads
3. Update Witness to query beads for polecat state
4. Remove state.json read/write code
5. Keep state.json as optional bootstrap cache (perf optimization only)

```
└──────┬──────┘  └──────┬──────┘  └──────┬──────┘
       └────────────────┼────────────────┘
                        ▼
              ~/gt/.events.jsonl (raw, audit)
                        │
              ┌─────────────────┐
              │  Feed daemon    │ ← goroutine in gt daemon
              │  - filters      │
              │  - aggregates   │
              │  - AI curates   │
              └────────┬────────┘
                       ▼
              ~/gt/.feed.jsonl (curated, user-facing)
```

## Event format

```json
{
  "ts": "2025-12-28T10:30:15Z",
  "source": "gt",
  "type": "sling",
  "actor": "mayor",
  "payload": {"bead": "gt-xyz", "target": "gastown/Toast"},
  "visibility": "feed"
}
```

Visibility: `audit` | `feed` | `both`

## Implementation phases

1. **Event logging** - gt commands write to ~/gt/.events.jsonl
2. **Feed daemon** - goroutine in gt daemon tails events, writes curated feed
3. **Feed readers** - gt feed, gt dashboard read from .feed.jsonl
4. **AI curation** - future: haiku summarization for complex activity

title: Witness Role Definition
description:
You are the Witness - per-rig worker monitor. You watch polecats, nudge them
toward completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck
workers to the Mayor.

You do NOT do implementation work. Your job is oversight, not coding.

default_molecule: mol-witness-patrol
capabilities:
  - monitor_workers
  - nudge_stuck
  - pre_kill_verify
  - session_lifecycle
  - escalation

## Core Responsibilities

1. Monitor workers: Track polecat health and progress
2. Nudge: Prompt slow workers toward completion
3. Pre-kill verification: Ensure git state is clean before killing sessions
4. Session lifecycle: Kill sessions, update worker state
5. Self-cycling: Hand off to fresh session when context fills
6. Escalation: Report stuck workers to Mayor

Key principle: You own ALL per-worker cleanup. Mayor is never involved in
routine worker management.

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by the mol-witness-patrol molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Nudge Protocol

Progress through stages. Track nudge count per worker per issue.
- First Nudge (10+ min idle): Gentle inquiry
- Second Nudge (15 min): Direct question
- Third Nudge (20 min): Final warning
After 3 nudges with no progress -> escalate to Mayor

## Pre-Kill Verification

Before killing ANY polecat session:
1. gt polecat git-state <name> - Must be clean
2. Check for uncommitted work
3. Check for unpushed commits
4. Verify issue closed
5. Verify PR submitted (if applicable)

## Commands

- gt polecat list <rig> - See all polecats
- gt polecat git-state <name> - Check git cleanliness
- tmux capture-pane -t gt-<rig>-<name> -p | tail -40 - Session inspection
- gt mail inbox - Check messages

title: Agent state lifecycle incomplete for polecats
description:
## Problem

The witness patrol formula (mol-witness-patrol.formula.toml) expects polecats to self-report states:
- running
- idle
- stuck
- done

But looking at the code, the only state transitions that actually happen are:

1. **spawning** - Set when polecat is created (polecat/manager.go:170)
2. **running** - Set when agent runs `gt prime` (prime.go:112)
3. **dead** - Set by daemon when agent goes unresponsive (daemon/lifecycle.go:647)

**Missing transitions:**
- `stuck` - No code path exists for agents to report this
- `done` - No code path exists for agents to report this
- `idle` - Only set for infrastructure agents, never for polecats

## Impact

The witness cannot rely on agent_state to detect stuck or done polecats, contradicting the ZFC principle stated in the formula.

## Found in commit

f3a6ef6 (feat: Witness reads polecat state from agent beads)

## Suggested fix

Add code paths for polecats to self-report:
1. `gt done` should update agent_state to "done"
2. When stuck (detected how?), agent should update to "stuck"
3. Consider if "idle" makes sense for polecats (no current work)

title: Witness should verify polecat submitted before stopping session
description:
## Problem

Witness stopped dementus's session before it could call `gt done`, losing the MR submission. I had to manually push and submit the branch.

## Root Cause

Witness cleanup is triggered by nudge/manual check rather than by receiving POLECAT_DONE message. When Witness cleans up based on issue status (closed), it doesn't wait for the polecat to complete its shutdown sequence.

## Expected Behavior

Witness should only stop a polecat session after:
1. Receiving POLECAT_DONE message from that polecat, OR
2. Timeout waiting for POLECAT_DONE after issue is closed

## Current Behavior

Witness stops sessions immediately when asked to check for completions, even if polecat hasn't called `gt done` yet.

## Fix

In mol-witness-patrol inbox-check step:
- Only clean up polecats that have sent POLECAT_DONE
- For polecats with closed issues but no DONE message, nudge them to complete
- Add timeout before force-killing

title: Add mutex to swarm.Manager for thread safety
description:
attached_args: Add swarm.Manager mutex for thread safety

Fix potential race condition in swarm manager's map access.

## Files to modify
- internal/swarm/manager.go
- internal/swarm/manager_test.go (add concurrency test)

## Problem
The swarms map[string]*Swarm is accessed without synchronization:
```go
type Manager struct {
    swarms map[string]*Swarm  // No mutex protection
}
```

Multiple goroutines could call Create(), GetSwarm(), etc. simultaneously.

## Implementation
```go
type Manager struct {
    mu     sync.RWMutex
    swarms map[string]*Swarm
}

func (m *Manager) GetSwarm(id string) *Swarm {
    m.mu.RLock()
    defer m.mu.RUnlock()
    return m.swarms[id]
}
```

## Acceptance criteria
- [ ] sync.RWMutex added to Manager struct
- [ ] All map accesses protected by mutex
- [ ] RLock for reads, Lock for writes
- [ ] Concurrency test added
- [ ] go test -race ./internal/swarm/... passes

title: Protocol: Type System for Formulas
description:
Protocols define interfaces that formulas implement - a type system for workflows.

## Concept

```toml
# reviewable.protocol
[protocol]
name = "Reviewable"

[requires]
steps = ["review"]  # Must have a step tagged "review"
outputs = ["review_decision"]  # Must produce this

[guarantees]
"review completes before any deploy step"
```

Formulas declare: `implements = ["Reviewable", "Deployable"]`

System verifies compliance statically.

## Use Cases

1. Ensure all deploy formulas have review steps
2. Define compliance requirements as protocols
3. Enable formula discovery: "Give me all Deployable formulas"
4. Validate formula composition compatibility

## Properties

- Static verification (before execution)
- Composable (protocol can extend protocol)
- Documentation value (self-describing contracts)

## Open Questions

1. Protocol syntax - embedded in formula or separate files?
2. Verification timing - cook time? load time?
3. Protocol versioning - how do protocols evolve?
4. Inheritance - can protocols extend other protocols?

- gt-8tmz - molecule algebra

title: Plugin system: subprocess JSON protocol
description:
Language-agnostic plugin system via subprocess JSON protocol.

## Concept

Allow extending Gas Town with external scripts/programs. Plugins communicate via stdin/stdout JSON.

## Protocol

Request (gt → plugin):
```json
{"method": "check", "params": {"rig": "wyvern", "polecat": "Toast"}}
```

Response (plugin → gt):
```json
{"result": {...}, "error": null}
```

Error response:
```json
{"result": null, "error": {"code": 1, "message": "..."}}
```

## Interface

```go
type Plugin struct {
    Name    string
    Path    string  // executable path
    Methods []string
}

type PluginManager struct {
    plugins map[string]*Plugin
}

func NewPluginManager() *PluginManager
func (pm *PluginManager) Register(plugin *Plugin) error
func (pm *PluginManager) Call(plugin, method string, params any) (any, error)
func (pm *PluginManager) Discover(dir string) error  // auto-discover plugins
```

## Plugin Discovery

Look in:
1. `<town>/plugins/`
2. `~/.config/gastown/plugins/`
3. System path with `gt-plugin-*` prefix

## Built-in Hooks

Plugins can register for events:
- `polecat.started` - Polecat session started
- `polecat.done` - Polecat signals done
- `merge.requested` - MR submitted
- `merge.completed` - MR merged

## Use Cases

- Custom health checks
- Integration with external systems (Slack, etc.)
- Custom merge policies
- Metrics collection

## Future

Consider MCP integration for richer plugin capabilities.

title: No-tmux mode: naked Claude Code operation without daemon/tmux
description:
## Problem

Tmux is crashing workers. The daemon relies on tmux for:
- Session management (creating/killing panes)
- Nudging agents via SendKeys
- Crash detection via pane-died hooks

When tmux is unstable, the entire Gas Town operation fails.

## Goal

Enable Gas Town to operate without tmux or the daemon, relying solely on:
- Naked Claude Code sessions (terminal or IDE)
- Deacon self-handoff and patrol robustness
- Pinned beads for propulsion (already implemented)
- **Beads as universal data plane** - args, context, everything flows through beads

## Key Insight: Beads Replace SendKeys

Currently --args is injected via tmux SendKeys. In no-tmux mode:
- Store args in the pinned bead description (attached_args field)
- gt prime reads and displays args from pinned bead
- Wisps are infinite ephemeral sticky notes - use them for transient context
- No prompt injection needed - agent discovers everything via bd show

## Degraded Behavior (No-Tmux Mode)

**What still works:**
- Propulsion via pinned beads (agents pick up work on startup)
- Self-handoff (agents can cycle themselves)
- Patrol loops (Deacon, Witness, Refinery keep running)
- Mail system (beads-based, no tmux needed)
- Args passed via bead description

**What is degraded:**
- **No interrupts**: Cannot nudge busy agents mid-task
- **Polling only**: Agents must actively check inbox (no push notifications)
- **Await steps block**: "Wait for human" steps require manual agent restart
- **No crash detection**: pane-died hooks unavailable
- **Manual startup**: Human must start each agent in separate terminal

**Workflow implications:**
- Patrol agents work fine (they poll as part of their loop)
- Task workers need restart to pick up new work
- Cannot redirect a busy worker to urgent task
- Human must monitor and restart crashed agents

## Requirements

1. **gt sling --args stores in bead**: Write args to pinned bead description
2. **gt prime displays args**: Read attached_args from pinned bead
3. **gt spawn --naked**: Assign work without creating tmux session
4. **Documentation**: Explain no-tmux mode and degraded behavior
5. **Deacon self-sustaining**: Must cycle reliably without daemon

## Acceptance Criteria

- Can assign work with args without tmux
- Agent discovers args via gt prime / bd show on startup
- Deacon patrol runs indefinitely via self-handoff
- Workers started manually pick up pinned work
- Documentation explains what works vs degraded in no-tmux mode

title: Deacon primes pending workers instead of spawn nudge
description:
## Problem

When gt spawn starts a polecat, it tries to send a nudge message immediately:
1. Starts tmux session with Claude Code
2. Waits 3 seconds (hardcoded)
3. Sends nudge via NudgeSession

But Claude Code takes 10-20+ seconds to be ready. The message arrives before
the prompt is ready, so it appears as part of the prompt string instead of
being executed.

## Solution

Move priming responsibility to the Deacon patrol cycle:

1. gt spawn: Mark polecat as pending_prime=true in state, return immediately
2. Deacon patrol: New step prime-pending-workers that:
   - Scans all rigs for workers with pending_prime=true
   - Uses WaitForClaudeReady() to poll for "> " prompt (already exists in tmux.go)
   - Once ready, sends gt prime + assignment nudge
   - Clears pending_prime flag

## Implementation

### spawn.go changes
- Remove the 3-second sleep (line 368)
- Remove the NudgeSession call (lines 375-383)
- Instead: Update polecat state with pending_prime=true

### Polecat state addition
status: assigned, pending_prime: true, issue: gt-xxx

### Deacon patrol addition
Add step between inbox-check and plugin-run:
prime-pending-workers: Check all rigs for workers marked pending_prime.
For each pending worker: WaitForClaudeReady(60s), then gt prime + nudge

### Benefits
- No race condition - we poll until actually ready
- Deacon already does health checks - priming is natural fit
- Works for polecats, witnesses, refineries, crew (unified approach)
- Timeout handling built in

## Depends on
- Existing WaitForClaudeReady() in tmux.go (lines 384-403)

title: Implement verification patterns for boot steps
description:
Define and implement the verification logic Mayor uses.

## Verification Utilities

Mayor needs to check:

### Session Exists
```bash
tmux has-session -t <session> 2>/dev/null && echo "exists"
```

### Not Stalled (Claude waiting at prompt)
```bash
gt peek <agent> 10 | grep -q "> Try" && echo "stalled"
```

Pattern: `> Try "..."` indicates Claude started but no message sent.

### Recent Heartbeat
```bash
# For deacon
age=$(( $(date +%s) - $(stat -f %m ~/gt/deacon/heartbeat.json) ))
[ $age -lt 120 ] && echo "fresh"
```

### Active Work Output
```bash
gt peek <agent> 20 | grep -q "⏺" && echo "working"
```

Pattern: `⏺` indicates Claude is executing tools.

## Mayor Execution Pattern

```
for each step in molecule:
  run action
  loop:
    check verification
    if verified: close step, continue
    if stalled: run on_stall recovery
    if timeout (5 attempts): log warning, continue
    sleep 10s
```

No hard timeout - Mayor keeps trying with increasing backoff.

title: Molecule Algebra: Work Composition DSL
description:
Implement the molecule algebra - a declarative language for composing, transforming, and executing structured work. Enables mechanical composition without AI.

The Three Phases: Rig → Cook → Run

- **Rig**: Source-level composition (formula YAML with extends/compose)
- **Cook**: Instantiation (formula → proto → mol/wisp)
- **Run**: Execution (agents complete steps)

Two Composition Operators:
- **Rig** operates on formulas (source level)
- **Bond** operates on artifacts (protos, mols, wisps)

Key components:
- Formulas: YAML source with composition rules (.formula.yaml)
- Cook: Pre-expand macros/aspects to flat proto
- Phase verbs (pour, wisp)
- Bond: Artifact-level polymorphic composition
- Composition operators (sequence, parallel, branch, loop, gate)
- Advice operators (before, after, around - Lisp style)
- Expansion operators (macros like Rule of Five)
- Aspects (AOP cross-cutting concerns)

See docs/rig-cook-run.md for the lifecycle spec.
See docs/molecule-algebra.md for full algebra specification.
Example formulas in .beads/formulas/

title: gt spawn: Enter key needs debounce delay after paste
description:
## Problem

When spawning polecats via `gt spawn`, instructions are pasted into tmux but workers often sit idle at prompt because the Enter key arrives before the paste is fully processed.

## Observed Behavior

- Instructions pasted via tmux send-keys
- Enter key sent immediately after
- Worker session shows prompt with no input (paste not submitted)
- Requires manual intervention to nudge workers

## Expected Behavior

- Paste completes fully
- Enter key submits the pasted instructions
- Worker begins executing immediately

## Root Cause

Likely a race condition between paste buffer processing and keypress handling. Need either:
1. Debounce delay before sending Enter
2. Longer delay (Tmax) to ensure paste completes
3. Alternative submission mechanism

## Impact

- Swarm of 10 workers had multiple stalls at startup
- Required manual tmux send-keys to unstick them
- Defeats purpose of automated spawning

## References

- Observed during Mad Max swarm (Dec 18, 2025)
- Affects gt spawn command in internal/cmd/spawn.go

title: gt spawn should create fresh polecat worktree, never reuse
description:
Currently gt spawn tries to reuse existing polecats, which causes:

1. Stale beads database
2. Stale code (behind main/integration)
3. Old inbox messages
4. Git history pollution

## Current Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Looks for idle polecat in pool
2. If found, reuses existing worktree
3. Assigns new issue

## Desired Behavior

gt spawn:
1. Always create FRESH polecat from current main/integration
2. Fresh worktree with clean beads
3. No reuse of old worktrees

## Name Pool Still Useful

Keep name pool for:
- Allocating themed names (mad-max, etc.)
- Tracking which names are in use

But worktrees should be created fresh each time.

## Implementation

In spawn.go, before starting work:
1. If worktree exists: remove it first
2. Create fresh worktree from integration branch
3. Sync beads from rig to polecat
4. Then proceed with work assignment

This ensures polecats always start with latest code and beads.

## Problem
Polecats linger after merge. Manual cleanup required.

## ZFC-Compliant Solution
Add step to `mol-witness-patrol.formula.toml`:

```toml
[[step]]
id = "cleanup-merged-polecats"
title = "Remove polecats after merge"
description = """
1. Check inbox for MERGED messages from refinery: gt mail inbox
2. For each MERGED notification:
   - Extract polecat name from message
   - Verify branch is actually gone: git branch -r | grep polecat/<name>
   - Kill session if running: tmux kill-session -t gt-<rig>-<polecat>
   - Remove worktree: gt polecat remove <rig>/<polecat> --force
   - Delete the MERGED mail
3. Log cleanup in state.json
"""
depends_on = ["check-ready-branches"]
```

## Why This Works
- Witness agent receives MERGED signal from refinery (mail)
- Agent verifies before acting (checks branch really gone)
- Agent runs gt/tmux commands
- No daemon code

- formulas/mol-witness-patrol.formula.toml

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: Architecture: Decentralized rig structure with per-rig agents
description:
## Decision

Adopt decentralized architecture where each rig contains all its agents (mayor/, witness/, refinery/, polecats/) rather than centralizing mayor clones at town level.

## Town Level Structure

```
~/ai/                              # Town root
├── config/                        # Town config (VISIBLE, not hidden)
│   ├── town.json                  # {"type": "town"}
│   ├── rigs.json                  # Registry of managed rigs
│   └── federation.json            # Wasteland config (future)
│
├── mayor/                         # Mayor's HOME at town level
│   ├── CLAUDE.md
│   ├── mail/inbox.jsonl
│   └── state.json
│
└── <rigs>/                        # Managed projects
```

## Rig Level Structure (e.g., wyvern)

```
wyvern/                            # Rig = clone of project repo
├── .git/info/exclude              # Gas Town adds: polecats/ refinery/ witness/ mayor/
├── .beads/                        # Beads (if project uses it)
├── [project files]                # Clean project code on main
│
├── polecats/                      # Worker clones
│   └── <name>/                    # Each is a git clone
│
├── refinery/
│   ├── rig/                       # Refinery's clone
│   ├── state.json
│   └── mail/inbox.jsonl
│
├── witness/                       # NEW: Per-rig pit boss
│   ├── rig/                       # Witness's clone
│   ├── state.json
│   └── mail/inbox.jsonl
│
└── mayor/
    ├── rig/                       # Mayor's clone for this rig
    └── state.json
```

## Key Decisions

1. **Visible config dir**: `config/` not `.gastown/` (models don't find hidden dirs)
2. **Witness per-rig**: Each rig has its own Witness (pit boss) with its own clone
3. **Mayor decentralized**: Mayor's clones live IN each rig at `<rig>/mayor/rig/`
4. **Minimal invasiveness**: Only `.git/info/exclude` modified, no commits to project
5. **Clone subdir name**: Keep `rig/` for consistency (refinery/rig/, witness/rig/, mayor/rig/)

## Role Detection

- Town root or mayor/ → Mayor (town level)
- Rig root → Mayor (canonical main)
- <rig>/mayor/rig/ → Mayor (rig-specific)
- <rig>/refinery/rig/ → Refinery
- <rig>/witness/rig/ → Witness
- <rig>/polecats/<name>/ → Polecat

## Migration from PGT

- `mayor/rigs/<rig>/` → `<rig>/mayor/rig/`
- `<rig>/town/` → eliminated (rig root IS the clone)
- Add `witness/` to each rig

title: Deacon CLAUDE.md for patrol execution
description:
Update Deacon role CLAUDE.md for patrol execution.

## Key Additions

### Role Definition

```markdown
## Your Role: DEACON

You are the Deacon - Gas Towns heartbeat process.
You run mol-deacon-patrol continuously.

Your job:
- Check mail for callbacks
- Spawn polecats for ready work
- Monitor rig health (basic)
- Cycle context when full
```

### Patrol Execution

```markdown
## Patrol Execution

You run mol-deacon-patrol on your hook.

On each heartbeat from the daemon:
1. Check your current step: bd hook
2. Execute that step
3. Advance: bd mol advance mol-deacon-patrol
4. If COMPLETE: restart the patrol or cycle context

The daemon keeps you alive. Your job is to run the patrol.
```

### Heartbeat Response

```markdown
## Heartbeat Response

When you see "HEARTBEAT: ..." from the daemon:
- If idle: check your hook, start/resume patrol
- If mid-step: continue working
- If waiting: the heartbeat reminds you to check state

Heartbeats are your clock tick. Use them.
```

### Context Cycling

```markdown
## Context Cycling

When context is high (>80%):
1. Write state to molecule
2. Run: gt handoff -s "Deacon cycling" -m "Context full"
3. Exit cleanly
4. Daemon respawns you
5. You wake, prime, read hook, continue
```

title: Campaign: Large-Scale Work Graph Execution
description:
A Campaign is a Molecule-wrapped Epic graph ready for orchestrated execution.

## Concept

Campaign = Molecule + Epics + Dependency Graph + Execution Strategy

Key properties:
1. **Work graph**: Linked epics with dependency edges (possibly from different authors)
2. **Combinators as glue**: >>, |, wrap define bridging/shaping between epics
3. **Molecule shell**: Provides execution state, persistence across sessions
4. **Witness-aware**: Can be parallelized across polecats on independent branches
5. **Single-rig scoped**: One rig executes it (spans sessions/polecats)

## The "Maximum Speed" Model

Witness becomes a scheduler that:
- Watches campaign progress
- Identifies ready nodes (all dependencies satisfied)
- Spawns/assigns polecats to ready nodes
- Respects parallelism constraints
- Handles failures (retry? skip? escalate?)

## Where Campaign Fits in MEOW

Campaign is the convergence point where work-tracking meets workflow-execution:
- An Epic-of-Epics (work dimension)
- A Molecule (workflow dimension)

## Open Questions

1. Campaign creation UX - manual wire vs declare intent?
2. Partial completion - can you commit progress and resume?
3. Distinct entity type or molecule with type="campaign"?
4. Cross-rig campaigns - can graph span multiple rigs?

## Related

- docs/formula_evolution.md - original discussion
- gt-8tmz - molecule algebra (foundation)

title: MQ smart scheduling: dependency-aware queue reordering
description:
Implement intelligent MQ reordering to minimize conflicts.

## Goal
Reorder the MQ so that MRs touching disjoint files merge "in parallel" (no conflicts), while MRs touching overlapping files are sequenced.

## Approach
1. For each MR, get list of changed files (from branch diff)
2. Build conflict graph: edge between MRs if files overlap
3. Find maximal independent sets (MRs that can merge in any order)
4. Schedule independent MRs first, then handle remaining sequentially

## Implementation
- Add file analysis to MR submission (gt done)
- Store changed_files in MR wisp
- Refinery sorts queue by: priority → conflicts → age

## Example
```
Queue: [A, B, C, D]
Files:
  A: auth/login.go
  B: payments/checkout.go  
  C: auth/login.go ← conflicts with A!
  D: docs/readme.md

Optimal: [A, B, D, C] - A, B, D can merge without waiting
```

title: Draft mol-ready-work protomolecule definition
description:
Draft the actual protomolecule definition in markdown format.

## Molecule Structure

```markdown
## Molecule: ready-work
Autonomous backlog processing patrol for crew workers.

Phase: vapor (wisp) - ephemeral patrol cycles
Squash: after each work item or context threshold

## Step: orient
Load context and check for interrupts:
- Read mail for overseer instructions
- Check for predecessor handoff
- Load current context state

## Step: scan-backlogs
Survey all backlogs in priority order:
1. gh pr list --state open
2. gh issue list --state open --label untriaged (or no label)
3. bd ready
4. gh issue list --state open --label triaged

Capture counts and candidates.

Needs: orient

## Step: select-work
Apply ROI heuristic to select best work item:
- Estimate size (tokens needed)
- Check remaining context capacity
- Weight by impact (priority, type)
- Select highest ROI achievable item
- If empty: exit patrol

Needs: scan-backlogs

## Step: execute-work
Work the selected item:
- For PRs: review, request changes, or merge
- For untriaged: triage and label
- For beads: implement and close
- For triaged GH: implement fix

Commit, push, close/update as appropriate.

Needs: select-work

## Step: check-context
Assess context state:
- Estimate remaining capacity
- If < 20%: goto handoff
- If ok: loop to scan-backlogs

Needs: execute-work

## Step: handoff
Prepare for session transition:
- Summarize work completed this cycle
- Note any in-progress items
- Send handoff mail to self
- Squash wisp to digest
- Exit for fresh session

Needs: check-context
```

## Variables

- `backlog_priority`: Override backlog scan order
- `context_threshold`: Percentage at which to handoff (default: 20)
- `max_items`: Maximum items to process per session

## Notes

- This is a vapor-phase molecule (wisp)
- Each work item should squash to a digest
- The patrol itself squashes at handoff

title: CLI API Audit: gt and bd command structure review before OSS launch
description:
# CLI API Audit for OSS Launch

Before launching Gas Town + Beads as an SDK, we need to ensure the command-line
API is intelligently designed, consistent, intuitive, and structurally sound.

## Current State Audit

### gt (Gas Town) - 50+ top-level commands

**Agent Lifecycle:**
- `gt mayor`, `gt deacon`, `gt witness`, `gt refinery` - agent management
- `gt polecat` - worker management (subcommands: add, remove, list, etc.)
- `gt crew` - persistent workspace management
- `gt spawn` - create polecat with work

**Work Lifecycle:**
- `gt spawn` - assign work to new polecat
- `gt sling` - hook work + start immediately
- `gt hook` - attach work durably
- `gt handoff` - pass work to fresh session
- `gt done` - signal work complete
- `gt release` - release stuck issues

**Infrastructure:**
- `gt daemon`, `gt up`, `gt down`, `gt start`, `gt stop`, `gt shutdown`
- `gt init`, `gt install`, `gt doctor`

**Communication:**
- `gt mail` (subcommands: send, inbox, read, etc.)
- `gt nudge`, `gt broadcast`

**Molecules:**
- `gt molecule` / `gt mol` (17 subcommands!)

### bd (Beads) - Well-categorized but some sprawl

**Core CRUD:**
- `bd create`, `bd show`, `bd update`, `bd close`, `bd list`

**Molecules:**
- `bd mol` (5 subcommands: catalog, show, bond, run, distill)
- `bd wisp` (3 subcommands: create, gc, list)
- `bd pour` (top-level alias for instantiation)
- `bd cook` (compile formula to proto)

**Hook/Pin:**
- `bd pin` - attach mol to agent hook
- `bd unpin` - remove from hook
- `bd hook` - inspect what's on hook

## Structural Concerns

### 1. gt is sprawling (50+ top-level commands)

Many commands could be subcommands:
```
# Current                      # Could be
gt up/down/start/stop         gt daemon {up|down|start|stop}
gt spawn/sling/hook/handoff   gt work {spawn|sling|hook|handoff}
gt mayor/deacon/witness       gt agent {mayor|deacon|witness|...}
```

### 2. Overlap between gt and bd

| Concept | gt | bd |
|---------|----|----|
| Hook | `gt hook` | `bd pin`, `bd hook` |
| Mail | `gt mail` | `bd mail` (delegates) |
| Molecules | `gt mol` (17 cmds) | `bd mol` (5 cmds) |

Which owns what? User confusion likely.

### 3. Naming inconsistencies

- `gt polecat` (noun) vs `gt spawn` (verb) - both about polecats
- `gt done` vs `gt handoff` - both end work but different
- `bd mol run` vs `bd pour` - both instantiate

### 4. Subcommand depth decisions

**Good patterns:**
- `bd mol {catalog|show|bond|run|distill}` - coherent group
- `gt mail {send|inbox|read|archive}` - coherent group

**Questionable patterns:**
- `bd create --wisp` AND `bd wisp create` - two ways to do same thing
- `gt spawn --molecule X` AND `gt mol instantiate` - overlap

### 5. Flag vs subcommand guidelines needed

When to use flags vs subcommands?
- `--json` as flag ✓ (modifier)
- `--wisp` as flag for create? Or separate `bd wisp create`?
- `--molecule` on spawn? Or separate workflow?

## Recommendations to Evaluate

### A. Consolidate gt top-level commands

Group related commands:
```
gt agent {mayor|deacon|witness|refinery|polecat}
gt work {spawn|sling|hook|handoff|done}
gt infra {daemon|up|down|doctor}
```

### B. Clarify gt vs bd ownership

| Domain | Owner | Other defers |
|--------|-------|--------------|
| Issues | bd | gt uses bd |
| Agents | gt | bd doesn't touch |
| Molecules | bd mol | gt mol wraps for UX |
| Hooks | bd pin/hook | gt hook wraps |
| Mail | gt mail | bd mail delegates |

### C. Apply consistent naming

- All agent commands: nouns (`gt polecat`, `gt mayor`)
- All work commands: verbs (`gt spawn`, `gt sling`, `gt hook`)
- Avoid synonyms: pick one term and stick with it

### D. Flag vs subcommand rule

- Flags: modify behavior of command (`--json`, `--force`, `--wisp`)
- Subcommands: distinct operations (`mol run`, `mol squash`, `mol burn`)
- Exception: very common operations can have top-level aliases

## Tasks

1. [ ] Review gt command groupings - propose consolidation
2. [ ] Review bd command groupings - check for sprawl
3. [ ] Document gt vs bd ownership boundaries
4. [ ] Identify and resolve naming inconsistencies
5. [ ] Document flag vs subcommand decision criteria
6. [ ] Create migration plan for any breaking changes
7. [ ] Update help text to be consistent
8. [ ] Test agent UX: can Claude guess commands correctly?

## Success Criteria

- New user can guess command structure intuitively
- `gt --help` fits on one screen (or is well-categorized)
- No duplicate functionality between gt and bd
- Consistent naming throughout
- Claude agents can discover commands without documentation

title: gt sling: auto-sync beads in new polecat worktrees
description:
## Problem
`gt sling <bead> <rig>` could fail to pin because polecat worktree branches persisted and diverged from current state.

## Root Cause
- Polecat branches (`polecat/<name>`) were reused across runs
- Stale branches could diverge from main and beads-sync
- Branch reuse logic was complex with fallback behavior

## Solution Implemented
**Fresh unique branches per polecat run**

Instead of syncing beads (Options A/B/C), we changed the branch model:

1. **Unique timestamped branches**: Each polecat run creates `polecat/<name>-<timestamp>`
2. **No branch reuse**: Each spawn starts fresh from current HEAD
3. **Simplified code**: Removed branch existence checks and reset logic
4. **Garbage collection**: Added `gt polecat gc <rig>` to clean up old branches

### Why This Works
- Polecats already use beads redirect (`../../mayor/rig/.beads`)
- Mayor's beads are authoritative - polecats read from there
- Fresh branches ensure clean starting state

title: Mol Mall: Formula marketplace and aspect composition
description:
## Summary

A marketplace for sharing molecule formulas using GitHub as backend, plus a new
**aspect composition** capability for cooking that allows formulas to be applied
as cross-cutting transformations to existing mols.

## Key Insight

Formulas aren't just standalone workflows—they're **transformations** you can
apply to other mols. This enables patterns like:
- "Apply Rule of Five code review to any coding task"
- "Wrap any epic with security review steps"
- "Add logging/metrics to any patrol molecule"

## Architecture

```
Remote Formulas (GitHub)
        ↓ install
Local Formulas (~/.gt/formulas/ or .beads/formulas/)
        ↓ cook --with
Mols (beads, git-tracked)
        ↓ pour/sling
Execution (ephemeral or tracked)
```

## Formula Types

1. **Standalone** - Complete workflows (mol-polecat-work, mol-deacon-patrol)
2. **Aspects** - Cross-cutting concerns woven into other mols (rule-of-five)
3. **Adapters** - Wrappers that make things runnable

## Aspect Composition (New Cooking Capability)

```bash
bd cook my-epic --with rule-of-five,security-review
```

Aspects declare injection points:

```yaml
# rule-of-five.formula.yaml
kind: aspect
name: rule-of-five
version: 1.2.0

inject_after:
  tag: generates-code  # matches any step with this tag

steps:
  - id: review-correctness
    title: "Review: Correctness"
  - id: review-edge-cases
    title: "Review: Edge Cases"
  - id: review-performance
    title: "Review: Performance"
  - id: review-security
    title: "Review: Security"
  - id: review-maintainability
    title: "Review: Maintainability"
```

Injection modes:
- `inject_after: <step-id or tag>` - insert steps after
- `inject_before: <step-id or tag>` - insert steps before
- `wrap: <step-id or tag>` - insert before AND after
- `replace: <step-id or tag>` - substitute entirely

## The Mall Index

A well-known repo maps short names to full references:

```yaml
# steveyegge/gt-mall/index.yaml
formulas:
  rule-of-five:
    repo: steveyegge/gt-formulas
    path: aspects/rule-of-five.formula.yaml
    version: v1.2.0
    description: "Five-lens code review"
    tags: [review, quality]
```

Commands:
- `gt mol search review` - search the index
- `gt mol install rule-of-five` - fetch from GitHub
- `gt mol install github.com/acme/formulas/custom@v1` - direct URL

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Aspect Composition (Cooking)
- Extend `bd cook` to accept `--with aspect1,aspect2`
- Aspect application during mol generation
- Local aspects in `.beads/formulas/`

### Phase 2: Mall Index
- Create gt-mall repo with index.yaml
- `gt mol search` queries the index
- `gt mol install` fetches and caches formulas

### Phase 3: Publishing
- `gt mol publish` pushes to your formula repo
- PR workflow to add to mall index

### Phase 4: Refinements
- Aspect ordering and conflict detection
- Aspect dependencies (`requires: [other-aspect]`)
- Private formula repos (enterprise)
- Local overrides/forks

## Open Questions

1. **Ordering conflicts**: Two aspects inject after same step—which goes first?
2. **Aspect dependencies**: Aspect A requires aspect B?
3. **Compile-time vs runtime**: Aspects are compile-time (baked into mol).
   Wisps remain runtime (slung dynamically).

## Deferred Until

Gas Town patrols operational. Prerequisites:
- [ ] Patrol system working (Deacon, Witness, Refinery)
- [ ] Basic spawn/work/merge cycle
- [ ] Activity feed showing work progress

Then the mall becomes valuable for sharing patrol customizations.

## Supersedes

This replaces gt-uzf2l which had the original marketplace concept but lacked
the aspect composition insight.

## Related

- Cooking system (bd cook)
- Formula definitions (.formula.yaml)
- Wisp architecture (runtime molecules)
notes: See docs/formula_evolution.md for expanded thinking on: formula resolution hierarchy, combinators (>>, |, wrap, inject, extends), algebraic properties, higher abstractions, Mol Mall registry predictions, distribution scenarios, and open questions. The aspect composition in this design corresponds to the Wrapping (AOP) and Injection combinators in that doc.

description:
gt spawn notifies the Deacon (via mail) that a polecat was started, expecting the Deacon to trigger it once Claude is ready. But if the daemon isn't running, the mail sits unread and the polecat never gets triggered.

## Current Behavior
1. gt spawn starts polecat session
2. gt spawn sends POLECAT_STARTED to deacon/
3. (assumes daemon will trigger polecat)

## Problem
If gt daemon isn't running, step 3 never happens and polecat sits at prompt.

## Solution
In gt spawn, after session start:
1. Check if daemon is running (gt daemon status)
2. If not running, either:
   a. Start daemon: gt daemon start
   b. Or warn user: 'Daemon not running, polecat may not auto-start'

The user can manually trigger with gt nudge, but automated flow should work.

title: Session cycling UX: smooth transitions via TUI wrapper
description:
## Problem

Current CLI agent session cycling is painful:
- Shell → CC starts → priming → context loads → ready → work → exit/crash → repeat
- Each cycle is 30-60 seconds of cold boot
- No continuity between shell and agent's inner state
- Raw "session not running, starting..." loop is the baseline

## GGT Advantages (already have)

- Beads: Work state survives session death completely
- Mail: Handoff notes from past-self to future-self  
- Prime commands: Structured context reload

## Gap: Transition Mechanics

Ideas to explore when actively using CLI:

1. **In-band cycling** - `/restart` or `/cycle` command, agent handles own restart without dropping to shell

2. **Hot standby** - TUI maintains pre-warmed session in background, switch to already-primed agent

3. **Persistent wrapper** - Bubbletea TUI stays running across session cycles, CC sessions come/go inside it

4. **Session pooling** - Keep 2-3 primed sessions ready, never wait for cold start

## Deferred

Deliberately P4 until we're actively using the simpler CLI and feel the pain firsthand.

title: Town Doctor molecule for harness health checks
description:
Create a Town Doctor molecule that any Gas Town agent can run to diagnose and repair harness issues.

## Concept

Instead of just `gt doctor` as a CLI command with hardcoded checks, create a **molecule** (checklist workflow) that:
- Any agent (Mayor, Witness, Polecat) can instantiate
- Walks the agent through diagnostic steps
- Agent uses judgment to fix issues found
- Works as a structured troubleshooting guide

## Why a Molecule?

1. **Agent-driven**: The agent running it becomes "the doctor" temporarily
2. **Extensible**: Add new checks by updating the molecule, not code
3. **Contextual**: Agent can reason about issues, not just run scripts
4. **Self-healing**: Agent can fix problems it finds, not just report them

## Proposed Checks (molecule steps)

1. Verify harness structure (mayor/, .beads/, CLAUDE.md exist)
2. Validate config files (town.json, rigs.json parse correctly)
3. Check beads health (bd doctor, redirect validity)
4. Verify git state (clean working tree, proper remotes)
5. Check rig integrity (each registered rig exists, has config.json)
6. Validate agent clones (mayor/rig/, refinery/rig/ exist and are valid)
7. Check for orphaned worktrees/branches
8. Verify daemon state (if running)

## Integration

- `gt doctor` could instantiate the molecule for the current agent
- Or agent can run `bd ready` and pick up doctor tasks when prioritized
- Results logged to beads for audit trail

## Related

- gt-cr9: Harness Design & Documentation (completed)
- Molecules design in architecture.md

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.

title: Replaceable notifications via Claude Code queue
description:
Leverage Claude Code's ability to replace queued text for notifications that supersede previous ones.

## Problem

If daemon sends 10 heartbeats while agent is busy, agent returns to see 10 stacked messages. Wasteful and noisy.

## Solution

Use Claude Code's queue replacement for:
- Heartbeat messages (only latest matters)
- Status updates that supersede previous
- Progress notifications

## Implementation

Notifications get a 'slot' identifier. New notification in same slot replaces old one:
- Slot: 'heartbeat' → only one heartbeat queued at a time
- Slot: 'status-<rig>' → latest status per rig
- No slot → stacks normally (for unique messages)

## Research Needed

- How does Claude Code expose queue replacement?
- tmux send-keys behavior with pending input
- Alternative: clear + resend pattern

title: Consolidate configuration architecture: three-tier model
description:
Rationalize Gas Town's scattered configuration into a clean three-tier model:

## Current Problems
- Config split across mayor/, .gastown/, and rig/config.json
- Runtime state mixed with configuration
- Hidden directories (.gastown/) are missed by agents
- Category confusion: identity vs config vs runtime state

## Proposed Architecture

### Tier 1: Town Config (mayor/)
```
mayor/
├── town.json      # Town identity (unchanged)
├── rigs.json      # Rig registry (unchanged)
└── config.json    # NEW: Town-level configuration
    # theme defaults, daemon settings, etc.
```

### Tier 2: Town Runtime (.runtime/)
```
~/gt/.runtime/                    # NEW: Gitignored
├── daemon.json                   # {pid, started_at, heartbeat}
├── deacon.json                   # {cycle, last_action}
└── agent-requests.json           # Lifecycle requests
```

### Tier 3: Rig Config (settings/)
```
<rig>/
├── config.json                   # Rig identity only (type, git_url, beads.prefix)
├── settings/                     # NEW: Visible, git-tracked
│   ├── config.json               # theme, merge_queue, max_workers
│   ├── namepool.json             # pool settings (style, max)
│   └── roles/                    # Per-role overrides (optional)
└── .runtime/                     # NEW: Gitignored
    ├── witness.json              # {state, started_at, stats}
    ├── refinery.json             # {state, started_at, stats}
    └── namepool-state.json       # {in_use, overflow_next}
```

## Key Principles
1. **Visible > Hidden** for config agents need to find
2. **Git-tracked** for identity and config; **gitignored** for runtime
3. **Separation of concerns**: identity, config, runtime are distinct
4. **Locality**: town config at town root, rig config at rig root

## Migration
- Move .gastown/ contents to appropriate new locations
- Update all code that reads/writes these files
- Update .gitignore patterns
- Update documentation (architecture.md, CLAUDE.md)

title: Polecat wisp architecture: Proto → Wisp → Mol pattern
description:
Design the three-layer architecture for polecat lifecycle:

## The Insight

Polecats should run a ONE-SHOT WISP (not looping like patrols):

**Step 1: Onboard**
- Read full polecat protocol (polecat.md template)
- Learn Gas Town operation, exit strategies, molecule protocol
- This is the 'how to be a polecat' education

**Step 2: Execute Mol**
- Run the assigned molecule (the actual work item)
- Could span multiple sessions via session continuity
- The mol is pure work content (epic, issue, feature)

**Step 3: Cleanup**
- Run final step of the wisp
- Self-delete / request shutdown

## Three Layers

- **Proto**: polecat.md template (instructions for being a polecat)
- **Wisp**: One-shot harness instantiated from proto (wraps the mol)
- **Mol**: The work item (issue/epic being processed)

## Why This Matters

1. **Separation of concerns**: Protocol (how) vs Work (what)
2. **Reusability**: Same wisp harness wraps any mol
3. **Extensibility**: Plugin points for custom behavior
4. **Session continuity**: Wisp handles multi-session, not the mol
5. **Blurred control/data planes**: Intentional in Gas Town

## Design Questions

1. How does proto (polecat.md) become a wisp instance?
2. What are the plugin/extension points?
3. Should all 'engineer in a box' mols use proto → wisp → mol?
4. How does this relate to refinery/deacon patterns?

## Overview

Docker container image for Cloud Run workers.

## Dockerfile

```dockerfile
FROM golang:1.21-alpine AS builder
WORKDIR /app
COPY . .
RUN go build -o gt ./cmd/gt

FROM ubuntu:22.04

# Install Claude Code
RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y     curl git nodejs npm     && npm install -g @anthropic-ai/claude-code     && apt-get clean

COPY --from=builder /app/gt /usr/local/bin/gt

EXPOSE 8080
ENTRYPOINT ["/entrypoint.sh"]
```

```bash
#!/bin/bash

git config --global user.email "$GIT_EMAIL"
```

title: Clarify Mayor vs Witness cleanup responsibilities
description:
Document the cleanup authority model: Witness owns ALL per-worker cleanup, Mayor never involved.

## The Rule

**Witness handles ALL per-worker cleanup. Mayor is never involved.**

## Why This Matters

1. Separation of concerns: Mayor strategic, Witness operational
2. Reduced coordination overhead: No back-and-forth for routine cleanup
3. Faster shutdown: Witness kills workers immediately upon verification
4. Cleaner escalation: Mayor only hears about problems

## What Witness Handles

- Verifying worker git state before kill
- Nudging workers to fix dirty state
- Killing worker sessions
- Updating worker state (sleep/wake)
- Logging verification results

## What Mayor Handles

- Receiving swarm complete notifications
- Deciding whether to start new swarms
- Handling escalations (stuck workers after 3 retries)
- Cross-rig coordination

## Escalation Path

Worker stuck -> Witness nudges (up to 3x) -> Witness escalates to Mayor -> Mayor decides: force kill, reassign, or human

## Anti-Patterns

DO NOT: Mayor asks Witness if worker X is clean
DO: Witness reports swarm complete, all workers verified

DO NOT: Mayor kills worker sessions directly
DO: Mayor tells Witness to abort swarm, Witness handles cleanup

DO NOT: Workers report done to Mayor
DO: Workers report to Witness, Witness aggregates and reports up

## Dog Agent Beads for @group Resolution

Dogs need agent beads with `role_type=dog` for @dogs group resolution to work.

## Background

Dogs are Deacon's reusable helper workers (see patrol-system-design.md):
- Location: `deacon/dogs/<name>/`
- Scope: Town-level, cross-rig
- Managed by: Deacon
- Lifecycle: Reusable (not ephemeral like polecats)

   ```bash
   bd create --type=agent --title="Dog: <name>" \
   ```

2. When `gt dog remove <name>` removes a dog, close the agent bead

3. Ensure `bd list --type=agent --role_type=dog` returns all dogs

## Schema

Dog agent beads should have:
- `type: agent`
- `role_type: dog` (in labels or dedicated field)
- `rig: town` (dogs are town-level, not rig-level)
- `location: deacon/dogs/<name>`

- gt dog add/remove commands (may not exist yet)
- Agent bead schema supports role_type

- Dog beads created/closed with dog lifecycle

title: mol-witness-patrol
description:
Per-rig worker monitor patrol loop using the Christmas Ornament pattern.

The Witness is the Pit Boss for your rig. You watch polecats, nudge them toward
completion, verify clean git state before kills, and escalate stuck workers.

**You do NOT do implementation work.** Your job is oversight, not coding.

## The Christmas Ornament Shape

This molecule uses dynamic bonding to create inspection arms per-polecat:

```
                    ★ mol-witness-patrol (trunk)
                   /|\
            ┌─────┘ │ └─────┐
         PREFLIGHT DISCOVERY CLEANUP
            │       │        │
        ┌───┴───┐ ┌─┴─┐  ┌───┴───┐
        │inbox  │ │sur│  │aggreg │
        │refnry │ │vey│  │save   │
        │load   │ └─┬─┘  │summary│
        └───────┘   │    │contxt │
                    │    │loop   │
          ┌─────────┼─────────┐ └───────┘
          │         │         │
          ●         ●         ●     mol-polecat-arm (dynamic)
         ace       nux      toast
          │         │         │
       ┌──┴──┐   ┌──┴──┐   ┌──┴──┐
       │cap  │   │cap  │   │cap  │
       │ass  │   │ass  │   │ass  │
       │dec  │   │dec  │   │dec  │
       │exec │   │exec │   │exec │
       └──┬──┘   └──┬──┘   └──┬──┘
          │         │         │
          └─────────┴─────────┘
                    │
                 ⬣ base (cleanup)
```

## Phases

### PREFLIGHT (fixed steps)
1. inbox-check - Process lifecycle requests, help messages
2. check-refinery - Ensure MQ is alive and processing
3. load-state - Read persistent state (nudge counts, etc.)

### DISCOVERY (spawns dynamic arms)
4. survey-workers - List polecats, bond mol-polecat-arm per polecat
5. run-plugins - Bond mol-plugin-runner for each witness plugin

### CLEANUP (gate + fixed steps)
6. aggregate - GATE: WaitsFor all arms + plugins to complete
7. save-state - Persist nudge counts, action log
8. generate-summary - Create digest content
9. context-check - Check if context is high
10. burn-or-loop - Squash/burn wisp, then loop or exit

## Dynamic Arms

Each polecat gets mol-polecat-arm bonded as a wisp child:
- capture - Capture tmux output
- assess - Categorize state (working/idle/error/done)
- load-history - Get nudge counts for this polecat
- decide - Apply nudge matrix
- execute - Take action (nudge/kill/escalate/none)

Arms run in PARALLEL. The aggregate step waits for all to complete.

## Activity Feed

This design enables real-time visibility:

```
[14:32:08] + patrol-x7k.arm-ace bonded (5 steps)
[14:32:09] → patrol-x7k.arm-ace.capture in_progress
[14:32:10] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace.capture completed
[14:32:14] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace.decide completed (action: nudge-1)
[14:32:17] ✓ patrol-x7k.arm-ace COMPLETE
```

## Storage

- Wisp storage: .beads-wisp/ (ephemeral, gitignored)
- Persistent state: witness handoff bead (nudge counts, etc.)
- Digests: Squashed summaries in permanent beads

## Dependencies

- bd-xo1o: Dynamic Molecule Bonding epic (in beads rig)
  - bd mol bond with variable substitution
  - WaitsFor directive for fanout gates
  - Activity feed query

Labels: [template, christmas-ornament]

title: Witness: aggregate completion and notify Mayor
description:
## Problem
No signal when swarm completes. Mayor must manually check.

## ZFC-Compliant Solution
Add step to `mol-witness-patrol.formula.toml`:

```toml
[[step]]
id = "check-swarm-completion"
title = "Report swarm completion to Mayor"
description = """
1. Check state.json for active swarm tracking:
   - swarm_id, start_time, assigned_beads[], completed_beads[]
2. For each completed merge (from cleanup step):
   - Add bead to completed_beads
3. If all assigned_beads are in completed_beads:
   - Calculate duration
   - Send summary to Mayor:
     gt mail send mayor/ -s "SWARM_COMPLETE: <swarm_id>" -m "All N polecats merged in Xm"
   - Clear swarm tracking from state.json
"""
depends_on = ["cleanup-merged-polecats"]
```

## Swarm Initialization
When Mayor slings a batch, they should:
```bash
# Mayor creates swarm tracking
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "SWARM_START" -m '{"swarm_id": "batch-123", "beads": ["bd-a", "bd-b", "bd-c"]}'
```

Witness parses SWARM_START and initializes tracking in state.json.

## Why This Works
- Mayor initiates batch with SWARM_START mail
- Witness tracks progress in its own state
- Witness signals completion via mail
- All coordination is agent-to-agent via mail

## Files
- formulas/mol-witness-patrol.formula.toml

title: Refinery semantic merge processing loop
description:
Implement the Refinery semantic merge loop for processing polecat work.

## Overview

The Refinery is a fully empowered Claude Code agent that:
1. Fetches polecat branches
2. Merges to integration branch
3. Resolves conflicts semantically (re-implements if needed)
4. Runs tests
5. Escalates only when truly stuck

## Processing Loop

1. Check queue for completed tasks (polecat done, not yet merged)
2. For each task:
   - Fetch polecat branch
   - Attempt merge to integration/<swarm-id>
   - On conflict: semantic resolution (understand intent, re-implement)
   - Run tests if configured
   - On success: mark merged, file bead, notify witness
   - On failure: notify polecat (test fail) or escalate (stuck)
3. When all tasks merged: land integration to main

## Semantic Merge

When git merge fails, Refinery:
1. Reads polecat changes and beads issue
2. Understands intent
3. Re-implements on current integration branch
4. Only escalates if truly blocked

## Daemon Poking

Refinery is poked by:
- Daemon heartbeat (periodic)
- Witness notification (polecat done)
- Mayor request (check queue)

## Dependencies

Needs: gt-u1j.6 (mail), gt-u1j.3 (git), gt-u1j.14 (merge queue)

## Reference

See PGT ephemeral.py for branch operations.

- "boot up gas town"
- "bootstrap the town"
- "start gas town"
- "bring up the town"

Mayor runs the molecule manually (not via subagent):

```
1. Bond the proto: bd mol bond mol-gastown-boot --wisp
2. For each step:
```

title: CLI cleanup: Remove duplicate mol commands from gt
description:
## Problem
gt mol has commands that duplicate bd mol functionality:
- `gt mol catalog` (duplicate of `bd formula list`)
- `gt mol show` (duplicate of `bd mol show`)
- `gt mol squash` (duplicate of `bd mol squash`)
- `gt mol burn` (duplicate of `bd mol burn`)
- `gt mol bond` (duplicate of `bd mol bond`)

## Principle
- **bd** = beads operations (issues, molecules, formulas)
- **gt** = agent operations (sessions, communication, work dispatch)

gt should delegate to bd for beads operations, not duplicate them.

## Proposed Changes
Keep gt mol commands that are agent-specific:
- `gt mol status` - what is on MY hook
- `gt mol attach/detach` - hook management
- `gt mol current` - what should I work on
- `gt mol progress` - my progress through workflow

Remove/delegate to bd:
- `gt mol catalog` → use `bd formula list`
- `gt mol show` → use `bd mol show`
- `gt mol squash` → use `bd mol squash`
- `gt mol burn` → use `bd mol burn`
- `gt mol bond` → use `bd mol bond`

## Alternative
Keep as thin wrappers that just call bd, for convenience.

title: Polecat Arm (arm-toast)
description:
Single polecat inspection and action cycle.

This molecule is bonded dynamically by mol-witness-patrol's survey-workers step.
Each polecat being monitored gets one arm that runs in parallel with other arms.

## Variables

| Variable | Required | Description |
|----------|----------|-------------|
| polecat_name | Yes | Name of the polecat to inspect |
| rig | Yes | Rig containing the polecat |

## Step: capture
Capture recent tmux output for toast.

```bash
tmux capture-pane -t gt-gastown-toast -p | tail -50
```

Record:
- Last activity timestamp (when was last tool call?)
- Visible errors or stack traces
- Completion indicators ("Done", "Finished", etc.)

## Step: assess
Categorize polecat state based on captured output.

States:
- **working**: Recent tool calls, active processing
- **idle**: At prompt, no recent activity
- **error**: Showing errors or stack traces
- **requesting_shutdown**: Sent LIFECYCLE/Shutdown mail
- **done**: Showing completion indicators

Calculate: minutes since last activity.
Needs: capture

## Step: load-history
Read nudge history for toast from patrol state.

```
nudge_count = state.nudges[toast].count
last_nudge_time = state.nudges[toast].timestamp
```

This data was loaded by the parent patrol's load-state step and passed
to the arm via the bonding context.
Needs: assess

## Step: decide
Apply the nudge matrix to determine action for toast.

| State | Idle Time | Nudge Count | Action |
|-------|-----------|-------------|--------|
| working | any | any | none |
| idle | <10min | any | none |
| idle | 10-15min | 0 | nudge-1 (gentle) |
| idle | 15-20min | 1 | nudge-2 (direct) |
| idle | 20+min | 2 | nudge-3 (final) |
| idle | any | 3 | escalate |
| error | any | any | assess-severity |
| requesting_shutdown | any | any | pre-kill-verify |
| done | any | any | pre-kill-verify |

Nudge text:
1. "How's progress? Need any help?"
2. "Please wrap up soon. What's blocking you?"
3. "Final check. Will escalate in 5 min if no response."

Record decision and rationale.
Needs: load-history

## Step: execute
Take the decided action for toast.

**nudge-N**:
```bash
tmux send-keys -t gt-gastown-toast "{{nudge_text}}" Enter
```

**pre-kill-verify**:
```bash
cd polecats/toast
git status                    # Must be clean
git log origin/main..HEAD     # Check for unpushed
bd show <assigned-issue>      # Verify closed/deferred
```
If clean: kill session, remove worktree, delete branch
If dirty: record failure, retry next cycle

**escalate**:
```bash
gt mail send mayor/ -s "Escalation: toast stuck" -m "..."
```

**none**: No action needed.

Record: action taken, result, updated nudge count.
Needs: decide

## Output

The arm completes with:
- action_taken: none | nudge-1 | nudge-2 | nudge-3 | killed | escalated
- result: success | failed | pending
- updated_state: New nudge count and timestamp for toast

This data feeds back to the parent patrol's aggregate step.
---

title: Remove keepalive file infrastructure
description:
The keepalive mechanism (~/gt/daemon/activity.json) is deprecated in favor of feed-based wake.

**Current state:**
- keepalive.TouchTownActivity() writes to activity.json on every gt/bd command
- Daemon reads activity.json to calculate exponential backoff

**New model (feed-based wake):**
- Patrol agents subscribe to `bd activity --follow`
- Any beads mutation wakes agents within ~500ms
- Daemon heartbeat is recovery-focused, not wake-focused
- Read-only commands don't need to wake the town

**TODO:**
1. Remove keepalive.TouchTownActivity() calls from gt commands
2. Remove keepalive.ReadTownActivity() from daemon
3. Delete internal/keepalive package
4. Update daemon to use longer base heartbeat (recovery-focused)

**Whitelist consideration:**
Some read-only commands might need to wake (TBD):
- gt mail inbox (checking for work?)
- None identified yet

See docs/patrol-system-design.md for full feed-based wake design.

title: Add crew lifecycle support to Deacon
description:
Currently crew sessions (like gastown/crew/max, beads/crew/dave) are marked as 'human-managed' and excluded from automated lifecycle.

- `getManager(RoleCrew)` returns `"human"` (handoff.go:273)
- `gt handoff` for crew just prints a message, no lifecycle request sent
- Crew cannot request automated refresh from Deacon

## Desired State
Crew members should be able to request lifecycle actions from Deacon:
- `gt handoff --cycle` sends request to Deacon, which kills/restarts the crew session
- Useful when: context full, running molecules that need fresh session, automation

## Implementation
1. Change `getManager(RoleCrew)` to return `"deacon/"` (or new crew manager)
2. Teach Deacon to recognize crew session naming pattern
3. Add crew to Deacon's respawn loop handling
4. Test with `gt nudge` for reliable message delivery

## Use Case
Running a molecule (e.g., version-bump) and discovering mid-workflow that a fresh session is needed. Agent should be able to request refresh automatically rather than requiring human intervention.

- gt nudge: reliable message delivery to Claude sessions
- bd mol bond: molecule instantiation (coming in beads)

title: Polecat Role Definition
description:
You are a Polecat - an autonomous worker assigned to a specific issue.

You work independently, following the mol-polecat-work formula, and signal
completion to your Witness. You are transient - spawned for work, cleaned up
after completion.

default_molecule: mol-polecat-work
capabilities:
  - execute_assigned_work
  - git_operations
  - branch_management
  - completion_signaling

## Core Responsibilities

1. Execute your pinned molecule's steps
2. Maintain clean git state
3. Signal completion via gt done
4. Wait for Witness to handle lifecycle

## You Do NOT

- Push directly to main (Refinery merges)
- Kill your own session (Witness does cleanup)
- Skip verification steps
- Work on anything other than your assigned issue

## Propulsion Principle

If you find something on your hook, YOU RUN IT.

Your work is defined by your pinned molecule. Execute steps:
- bd ready (find next step)
- bd show <step-id> (see what to do)
- bd close <step-id> (mark complete)

## Completion Protocol

When done:
1. Tests pass: go test ./...
2. COMMIT changes: git add && git commit
3. Push branch: git push -u origin HEAD
4. Close issue: bd close <issue>
5. Sync beads: bd sync
6. Run gt done
7. WAIT: Witness will kill your session

## Communication

Mail your Witness when stuck:
gt mail send <rig>/witness -s "HELP: <problem>" -m "..."

title: Doctor framework: Check interface, Result types, Report
description:
Framework for gt doctor health checks.

## Check Interface

```go
type Check interface {
    Name() string
    Description() string
    Run(ctx *CheckContext) *CheckResult
    Fix(ctx *CheckContext) error  // optional auto-fix
    CanFix() bool
}

type CheckContext struct {
    TownRoot string
    RigName  string  // empty for town-level checks
    Verbose  bool
}

type CheckResult struct {
    Status  CheckStatus
    Message string
    Details []string  // additional info
    FixHint string    // suggestion if not auto-fixable
}

type CheckStatus int
const (
    StatusOK CheckStatus = iota
    StatusWarning
    StatusError
)
```

## Report

```go
type Report struct {
    Timestamp time.Time
    Checks    []CheckResult
    Summary   ReportSummary
}

type ReportSummary struct {
    Total    int
    OK       int
    Warnings int
    Errors   int
}

func (r *Report) Print(w io.Writer, verbose bool)
```

## Doctor Runner

```go
type Doctor struct {
    checks []Check
}

func NewDoctor() *Doctor
func (d *Doctor) Register(check Check)
func (d *Doctor) Run(ctx *CheckContext) *Report
func (d *Doctor) Fix(ctx *CheckContext) *Report  // run with auto-fix
```

## Built-in Checks

Town-level (gt-f9x.5):
- ConfigExists, ConfigValid
- StateExists, StateValid
- MayorMailboxExists
- RigsRegistryValid

Rig-level (gt-f9x.6):
- RigCloneExists
- GitExcludeConfigured
- WitnessExists, RefineryExists
- PolecatClonesValid

title: Auto-handoff: self-cycling with guaranteed work pickup
description:
## Summary

A mechanism for agents to self-cycle: send handoff mail, request Deacon to kill the process, and automatically restart to pick up the work.

## Use Case

User says: `auto-handoff: gt-bug3`

The agent:
1. Sends handoff mail documenting current state
2. Requests Deacon to terminate the session
3. Deacon restarts the agent in background
4. New session picks up the handoff and continues working

When the user returns to terminal, the old session is gone but work continues in background. User can reattach.

## Key Requirements

- **Guaranteed pickup**: Something in the hook and/or handoff must ensure the new session picks up the work (not just a passive "check inbox")
- **Background execution**: Work continues without user presence
- **Reattachability**: User can reconnect to see progress

## Design Questions

1. Can molecules help coordinate this? (e.g., molecule binds the handoff + auto-restart)
2. What hook handles the pickup guarantee? 
3. How does Deacon know to restart vs just kill?
4. How does user reattach to a background agent?

## Related

- Molecules system
- Deacon lifecycle management
- Handoff hooks

title: gt mail inbox doesn't find crew worker mail - identity mismatch
description:
## Problem

Crew workers don't see their handoff messages when running `gt mail inbox` from their working directory.

## Root Cause

gt derives identity from cwd path, but crew workers have a different path structure:
- **cwd**: `/Users/stevey/gt/beads/crew/dave`
- **gt derives**: `beads/crew/dave` (wrong)
- **should be**: `beads/dave` (crew workers use `rig/name` format)

Messages sent to `beads/dave` don't show up because gt is looking for `beads/crew/dave`.

## Workaround

Use explicit identity flag:
```bash
gt mail inbox --identity "beads/dave"
```

## Fix

Identity detection in gt should handle crew/ subdirectory:
- Path `<rig>/crew/<name>` should derive identity as `<rig>/<name>`
- This matches how polecats work: `<rig>/polecats/<name>` → `<rig>/<name>`

## Affected

All crew workers in all rigs.

title: Federation: Wasteland architecture for cross-town coordination
description:
## Overview

Federation enables Gas Town to scale across machines via **Outposts** - remote compute environments that can run workers.

**Design doc**: docs/federation-design.md

## Outpost Types

| Type | Description | Cost Model |
|------|-------------|------------|
| Local | Current model (tmux panes) | Free |
| SSH/VM | Full Gas Town clone on VM | Always-on |
| CloudRun | Container workers on GCP | Pay-per-use |

## Key Concepts

### Outpost Abstraction
```go
type Outpost interface {
    Name() string
    Type() OutpostType  // local, ssh, cloudrun
    MaxWorkers() int
    Spawn(issue string, config WorkerConfig) (Worker, error)
    Workers() []Worker
    Ping() error
}
```

### Cloud Run Workers
- Persistent HTTP/2 connections solve zero-to-one cold start
- Pay only when working (~$0.017 per 5-min session)
- Scale 0→N automatically
- Git clone via persistent volumes

### SSH/VM Outposts  
- Full Gas Town clone on remote machine
- SSH for commands, git for sync
- Good for long-running autonomous work

## Design Principles

1. **Outpost abstraction** - support multiple backends
2. **Local-first** - remote is for overflow/burst
3. **Git as source of truth** - code and beads sync everywhere
4. **HTTP for Cloud Run** - dont force mail onto containers
5. **Graceful degradation** - works with any subset of outposts

## Related

- gt-f9x.7-10: Connection interface (lower-level abstraction)
- docs/federation-design.md: Full architectural analysis
